review_title: Besides a soulful score by Ajay Atul, this adaptation of Ramayana is a baffling and collosal dissapointment.
review_text: Besides a soulful score by Ajay Atul, this adaptation of Ramayana is a baffling and collosal dissapointment.My Rating : 15/100Adipurush is a disgusting mockery of a beloved and celebrated chapter of Indian Mythology. Baring the intimidating Sharad Kelkar's voice and Ajay Atul's profound score, nothing really clicks in this modern adaptation. Om Raut's precarious attempt is a monumental disaster in every aspects of filmaking. Starting from the caricaturish character design of Raavan, cartoonish rendering of the banar sena , cringe dialogues & hurried screenplay everything forces us to bash this misfire. Some salvageable performanaces by Kriti Sanon and Devdatta Nage isnt quite enough to save this project. A mere cash-grabbing project with no acknowledgement of the source material , relying only to play with the Indian sentiments is the prime idea behind this.A proper case of poor casting, whoever decided to cast the stone faced Prabhas to portray the vibrant character of Ram should be easily disbanded from his casting career. A complete misfit as he stirs through with no expressions on his face. Entire film is shot in dark, in order to hide the already flawed CGI. Thor's Asgard is colour graded to black and they have the new Lanka. Wtf are you serious Om Raut? The entire films goes by and i couldn't find anything which i could have related or brought back home. A tiring adaptation to say the least.Overall, if you wish to see this film even if you re a Prabhas fan, you will be largely dissapointed. Only Prasanth Neel's Salaar can revive his degrading career. My suggestion would be to skip this in Theatres and show your kids the Yugo Sako animated version of The Legend of Prince Rama or Ramanand Sagar's version if ever you want them to learn this beautiful epic.Instagram & Twitter : @streamgenx.

Adipurush, if one remembers, was supposed to be an modern adaptation of Ramayan and hence the makers chose to have a free run with the creative liberties in this film and it all went wrong .Adipurush itself starts from the middle of Ramayana where lord Ram was sent to the jungles for 14 years exile . Hence the film doesn't have any build up to any character.First, the characters itself have no introduction whatsoever. Makers assume since we know Ramayana, so no need to introduce anyone properly. Lord Ram is just introduced through some pictures in the opening credit while laxman and Sita ma have even further lower introduction. Honestly saying if one didn't tell you that Sunny Singh is laxman, you probably won't know. Jatayu pops up randomly and gets to poorest adieu . It's almost as if Lord Ram doesn't even know who Jatayu is. Bali , the brother of Sugreev, has absolutely no introduction.Next, the setting. If it's a modern adaptation of Ramayana, then why is the Lord Ram side shown to be taken straight from Ramayana but Lanka and it's people especially Raavan are shown as people of some Azguard (Thor) ? Clearly there is inconsistency . If you remember the original Ramayana, both Ram and Raavan side had almost similar kind of dresses with kings wearing king like dresses etc. Here, both sides wear dresses belonging to opposite poles.Next, the execution. It's horrendous. Bali and Sugreev's fight is the worst looking one which gets over in no time without any introduction to Bali. As they fight, you can't even understand who is Bali and who is Sugreev. The part where Sita gets kidnapped by the Sadhu is not accurate. The Sadhu i believe never gave evil smiles . Jatayu's adieu is just ignored. In the earlier Ramayana, Jatayu has a heartfelt conversation with lord Ram in his arms before dying but here, Jatayu is just treated like a random bird. Last but not the least, everything on the lankan side is so poorly executed. Lord Hanuman burns Lanka with his tail but it barely burns, just random explosions here and there that's it.Next, I want to talk about Indrajith and Vibhishan. My god what kind of portrayal is this? Indrajit looks like a party animal from some Noida club and he possesses powers of Flash !! The level of creative liberties they took!! Vibhishan is so hard to believe he's vibhishan as he doesn't act like him only . They all got weird tattoos on their body especially indrajith . Itna bhi modern nahi karna tha !!VFX and dialogues. Let's not talk about it you already know how it is. The final war sequence also looks so cartoonish that it sucks the essence out of it.Let's talk about Raavan played by Saif. He does try very hard to make Raavan look menacing. His character is even given a terrifying bgm . However, the rest things of his looks so weird. His 10 heads rendered VFX looks hilarious at best. His hairstyle is again Noida Gurugram style. He feeds non veg to his dragon vehicle (why is non veg shown in this film at first place?). All these creative choices just don't fit Raavan. The makers have just played around with the Lanka side while fearfully avoiding any creative changes on Ram side .Songs are good as well as the BGM. That's the only reason I gave this film 2 stars.Prabhas as lord Ram should never have been there. He's just angry faced , barely smiles and has no expressions at all. His body is an entire VFX render throughout.Overall, i thought KBKJ was the worst film this year but Adipurush beats it by a mile solely because it has ruined an epic saga so close to all Hindus. Adipurush just shows a part of the entire Ramayana that too with little to no detailing with its running time being 3 hrs and back in 1992, the Yugo Sako version showed all details and the entire tale of Ram in under 2hrs 50 mins. It clearly shows the quality difference of the makers .

review_title: How can someone make a movie that bad ?
review_text:
Summary:
Adipurush, a movie supposedly based on the Hindu mythology Ramayan, proves to be a disastrous departure from tradition. With its misguided choices in visual effects, abysmal dialogues, and language inconsistencies, the film misses the mark on multiple levels.Detailed Review:
A question to the director and the other heads, how can you be so irresponsible while making this masterpiece of a story into something trash? The blatant disregard for retaining the original character personalities is appalling. Ravan, a Brahmin devotee of Shiv, known for his vegetarianism, is completely transformed in this movie, which not only disrespects the original mythology but also has the potential to hurt the religious sentiments of Hindus.Let's talk about the VFX, or rather the lack thereof. Despite having a higher budget than Brahmastra, Adipurush fails to achieve even a fraction of the visual effects quality. It's clear that more effort should have been put into fixing the VFX instead of just superficially color grading the scenes.The dialogues in Adipurush reach new depths of mediocrity. While attempting to portray a more modern interpretation, the filmmakers fail to put in the necessary effort to create dialogues that can be understood and appreciated by any generation. The result is a disjointed and poorly crafted script that leaves viewers cringing and yearning for substance.In conclusion, my disappointment with Adipurush is immeasurable, and it truly ruined my day. The film's disregard for character authenticity, subpar VFX, and atrocious dialogues render it an abysmal cinematic experience. It fails to deliver on its promise of an engaging and respectful adaptation of the revered Ramayan Epic. It serves as a disservice to both the source material and the audience, leaving a bitter taste in the mouths of those who had hoped for so much more.

Don't know where to really start from, this is an epic disappointment on all levels. And the fears really came true, the VFX is so poor that, you start to wonder if this is a beta version of a video game launched several years ago, it is that cartoonish and was an eyesore. Acting wise, none really standout, though the aggressive version of Lord Rama played into the strengths of Prabhas, he was just okayish, Kriti had just to smile and weep. Even with a caricaturish characterisation of Ravan, it was Saif who had put some genuine effort among all the cast and crew. Screenplay is so lazy, the dialogues at places are as cringeworthy as hell. Technically, for a 500Cr project, this has to be the biggest scam in Indian Cinema in the recent times, nothing much about cinematography, as the entire movie was shot indoor, editing is pathetic, action choreography was straight out of many Hollywood movies. Only saving grace is the songs of Ajay-Atul and the score of Sachet-Parampara, it really elevates the proceedings.Coming to director Om Raut, for a man who directed two critically and commercially successful ventures like Lokmanya and Tanhaji, he perhaps overestimated himself and probably went overconfident in directing this, some of the creative choices like Ravan and Lanka design might not go well with the staunch followers of Hindusim, his version of creating a commercial Ramanaya is the worst decision.Bottom-line: Wait for Salaar, stay away from this.

review_title: Pathetic ScreenPlay, Out of Context dialogues
review_text:
Manoj Muntashir what the hell u have made .....?Can't have worst depiction of holy ramayana than this movie
Out of Context and Derogatory dialoguesAdipurush is merely a Bollywood-ised version of one of the most epic tales that ever existed. If you keep the story aside for it's largely known to all, the execution turns out to be a messy blend of over-the-top CGI and passable VFX, and making it worse are the intentionally funny dialogues that sound misplaced in a sensitive and mythological story. Why would you want Hanuman to say 'Jalegi tere baap ki'?"Better to watch the ancient Ramayana rather then wasting time on this so called Epic.

It is everything , but not Ramayan . But my problem isn't even that , the problem how can you get the most basic history wrong.Problems with getting the story wrong
1) Casting : The first basic mistake . Prabhas looks like Ravan with moustache and aggressiveness . Kriti no where looks like Maa Sita , she looks like Devakanya . In this movie he was always shown cunning and dumb .5) Vanarsena : could be compared to Early Humans , but here they are shown as monkeys
6) Rama asks Vanarsena to fight for him : Rama never asked or encouraged the Vanarsena to fight for him , he just asked Sugreeva to help him .7) Rama : Lord Rama , calm and composed at all situations , but he is always shown aggresive .8) Hairstyles and Dressing : If you look at them , it feels like some tik tokers were in the movie . Scenes like Jambvant encouraging Hanuman , Hanuman bringing Sanjeevani , Ram Setu , nothing was powerful , it was so cheap . It could be ignored in OTT as well . Please watch Ram Anand Ramayan , it was so beautiful.Please , if you can't write a basic story on Ramayan don't . We won't accept this , why should you change our history . Leave VFX , at least the casting , or at least the story line wasn't perfect . A 6 years old kid knows the story better than you.

review_title: Don't waste your time and money
review_text: There should be less than 0 rating for such a bad movie, there is a huge difference between Ramayana and Adipurush movie. This movie has done the work of defaming the history of India and the history of Maryada Purushottam Shri Ram, people are watching the movie only to see Prabhas, otherwise a good movie cannot be made in favor of Hinduism from Bollywood everyone knows. None of the cast and crew of Adipurush would have read Ramayana, this is just the irony of Ramayana, it is a request to all Hindus, please do not watch this movie because through this movie, they want to tell a different history to the new generation.

Aadipurush, unfortunately, proves to be an immense letdown and a missed opportunity. The film's visual effects appear artificial and excessive, giving the impression that suitable shooting locations were lacking, leading to the decision to film every scene in a studio with green screens and relying heavily on post-processing effects.The casting choices are severely flawed. Hanuman's character, smaller in stature compared to Ram and Ravan, seems out of place. Throughout the film, Ram's character lacks any semblance of emotion, and there is a noticeable absence of charm on his face. Laxman's portrayal fails to do justice to the character, and the Vanar Sena appears to be a combination of monkeys and chimpanzees, indicating a lack of understanding from the director regarding the distinction between Vanars and other animals. Sita's character lacks the pride and grace befitting the traditional portrayal, instead being presented as a modern interpretation. Moreover, Ravan's character is depicted solely as a dark villain, disregarding his status as a knowledgeable Brahmin. These creative decisions substantially distort the story of Ramayan, misrepresenting several key aspects.The dialogue further adds to the film's disgrace. The characters communicate disrespectfully with each other. Prabhas, portraying Ram, addresses Sita by his father-in-law's name (Janki). Hanuman's character is muzzled, hindering proper communication. Most of the dialogue feels as if it were penned by an amateur writer, lacking the depth and knowledge expected from a well-versed writer.Witnessing this disrespect toward the Hindu epic was deeply disheartening. It is astonishing to contemplate how the actors, writers, and filmmakers could transform such a beautiful story into a subpar production. The film's failure is truly disheartening, as it squanders the opportunity to create a remarkable cinematic experience, instead delivering a dispiriting disappointment. The sheer magnitude of this disgrace compelled me to leave the theater before its conclusion.

Worst movie of the year 2023. VFX quality is childish. Acting of protagonists is 🤢. Costume designing is 🤧. Hairstyles are 😭.If you want to watch Ramayana, then go for Ramanand Sagar's RAMAYANA. You can watch it free on YouTube.Look, it's your choice, your money, whether you want to watch the movie on big screen or not.These 🤧 types of VFX and acting skills can be seen in Salman Khan's movies. There is no doubt about that.Mr. Director probably thought that Indian youths are dumb, and imotional to Sri Rama. So, they would sure go and watch the movie.Now, the real question:-Is it worthy to go to theater and watch the movie?Well, my suggestion is a big "NO".

review_title: Please Refund - They Sold This Movie Using Lord Ram's Name
review_text: First of all, I want to say something to Prabhas fans. This movie made money not because of Prabhas. This movie made money only because the name of Lord Rama and Lord Hanuman was thrown. The last two movies of Prabhas were super flop. This movie made money only because Hindu religious sentiments were involved and that's why people went to watch it, it's not because of Prabhas.One more reason is that, the makers scammed the audience in trailer, interviews, and various series of incidents before the movie.Before the premier of the movie, the dialogue writer said that, the whole movie is based on Ramayana, the Hindu epic. Now, after the movie is released, him and including others are claiming that it is not based on Ramayana, after they were charged for blasphemy in Delhi High court.Now, when they say that this movie is not based on Ramayana, they are still using these names of Lord Rama, Hanuman, Sita or Jankai, Lankesh or Dashanan or Ravana, Bali, Sugriv, etc. All these names, all these characters, are based on Ramayana. This is the basis that this movie should be banned for blasphemy and hurting religious sentiments of billions of Hindu followers all over the world.Next, they took six more months time to fix the movie. That was indeed not to fix the movie but to plan the methods to trick and deceive the audience so that they buy the tickets.For example, keeping one seat empty for Lord Hanuman in every theatres was a publicity stunt too. They even captured a monkey in Telangana and placed it on theatres to get the attention.Still, after six months, the only thing they changed in the movie was the saturation and brightness. They made brighter scenes darker and dark scenes brighter to hide the details and flaws. The whole movie was dark, couldn't see anything even after using a torch.Talking about details, the cheap 3D models were just downloaded from the internet. I personally checked and found one of monsters shown in the movie, already available on the internet.They downloaded those models and slightly modified them, like the facial expression, so that people won't identify. Thankfully, I caught them doing so and immediately identified those models as I am a game developer myself and I have used one of them in my video game already before they used it the movie.I have the 3d file saved on my computer. It is ditto to the monster shown in Adipurush, just a few facial expressions are changed.This movie is a total scam. They said 600 crores budget, but the actual investment is $0 as those 3D models are already available. I'm angry man. I don't want to write anything more.And, lastly, Prabhas fans, shame on you and shame on your brain and mindset for considering Prabhas sold this movie. This movie was sold in the name of Lord Rama and Lord Hanuman, not that clown Prabhas. The whole movie is clownish and insult to Hinduism.Foreigners who don't know the actual Ramayana will think that this is the real Ramayana. Therefore, Adipursh is an insult to our religion and culture, it should be banned permanently and the people who were scammed should be refunded their money back.

review_title: Watch if you wanna know how to make bad movie.
review_text: Adipurush, a much-anticipated film starring Prabhas, Saif Ali Khan, and Kriti Sanon, fails to live up to the expectations of its viewers. Despite a promising premise and a talented cast, the movie falls short in multiple aspects, leaving the audience unsatisfied and disillusioned.One of the major letdowns of Adipurush lies in its character development. Prabhas, known for his charismatic presence on-screen, fails to justify his role as the protagonist. His performance lacks depth and fails to evoke the necessary emotions that could have brought the character to life. Similarly, Saif Ali Khan and Kriti Sanon also struggle to make a lasting impact, as their characters feel underdeveloped and fail to leave a lasting impression.Another glaring issue with Adipurush is its screenplay and dialogue. The film relies heavily on overhyped and low-impact dialogues that do not resonate with the audience. The lack of impactful writing makes it difficult for the viewers to connect with the story or the characters, leading to a sense of detachment throughout the movie.Furthermore, the visual effects in Adipurush, touted as one of its strengths, turn out to be lackluster. The CGI (Computer-Generated Imagery) feels unpolished and fails to seamlessly blend with the live-action sequences. The result is a jarring and unconvincing visual experience that takes away from the overall immersion in the film.The filmmakers had the opportunity to elevate Adipurush by focusing on simplicity and utilizing a more accessible language. However, they missed the mark by overcomplicating the narrative and using convoluted storytelling techniques. As a result, the movie becomes unnecessarily convoluted and difficult to follow, leaving the audience feeling disconnected and perplexed.In conclusion, Adipurush is a disappointing film that fails to capitalize on its potential. The lackluster character development, underwhelming performances, weak dialogue, and unimpressive visual effects contribute to its downfall. While it had the ingredients for success, the execution falls short, resulting in a wasted opportunity. Ultimately, this movie fails to leave a lasting impact and will likely leave viewers feeling unsatisfied and unfulfilled.

review_title: Totally disappointed due to many reasons
review_text: I recently watched a movie that left much to be desired. The visual effects were subpar, lacking the polish and realism expected from modern cinema. The background music failed to create the desired atmosphere, often feeling out of place or generic. Additionally, the makeup applied to the characters was poorly executed, detracting from their believability. Overall, this film fell short in multiple areas, making it a disappointing experience that failed to live up to its potential.Don't watch, instead see Japanese Ramayan and show to you children the masterpiece.

review_title: Adipurush: A Disappointing and Controversial Adaptation
review_text: Adipurush, despite generating immense anticipation, fails to meet the expectations set for it. Marketed as a grand spectacle, the film disappoints on various fronts. The CGI work, which was supposed to be extravagant, turns out to be subpar, lacking the finesse and attention to detail that one would expect from a high-budget production. The underwhelming visual effects further contribute to the film's lackluster presentation, leaving viewers disengaged and unimpressed with the story.The sentiments of many Hindus were hurt by this film. Adipurush takes liberties with the revered story of Ramayana, altering its narrative, characterization, language, and even resorting to poorly written dialogues. This creative license comes at the cost of the film's integrity and disrespects the source material, leaving a bitter taste for those familiar with the original tale. It is disheartening to witness Bollywood continue to disregard Hindu sentiments for the sake of entertainment.Ultimately, Adipurush emerges as a highly disappointing and controversial adaptation, leaving audiences yearning for a more respectful and faithful retelling of the epic.

I recently had the opportunity to watch Adipurush, a movie supposedly based on the Hindu mythology Ramayan. I wanted to take a moment to share my feedback and express my disappointment with the overall execution of the film.Firstly, I must mention that the departure from the traditional portrayal of characters in Adipurush was quite disheartening. Ravan, a revered character known for his devotion to Lord Shiva and his strict vegetarianism, was portrayed in a manner that completely disregarded these important aspects. This not only deviated from the original mythology but also had the potential to hurt the religious sentiments of Hindus who hold the Ramayan Epic in high regard.Moving on to the visual effects (VFX), it was quite evident that the film fell short in this aspect. Despite having a higher budget than Brahmastra, the VFX in Adipurush failed to impress. It seemed as though more attention was given to superficial color grading rather than focusing on achieving high-quality visual effects that would enhance the overall viewing experience.Additionally, the dialogues in the film were quite disappointing. While attempting to present a more modern interpretation, it felt like the important characters like Raavan and Hanuman were more like goons living in slum areas.In summary, Adipurush proved to be a disastrous departure from tradition. The film's misguided choices in character portrayal, subpar visual effects, and abysmal dialogues made it an underwhelming cinematic experience. It failed to deliver on its promise of an engaging and respectful adaptation of the revered Ramayan Epic. As an audience member, my disappointment was profound, and it truly affected my overall impression of the film.I hope that Adipurush team takes all these negative feedback into consideration for future projects. I believe that with the right attention to detail and a sincere commitment to honoring the source material, it is possible to create adaptations that resonate with audiences and do justice to the rich mythology they are based on.

review_title: Adipurush: A Disappointing and Misguided Interpretation
review_text: Director Om Raut's highly anticipated film "Adipurush" promised to be a grand retelling of the epic Ramayan with a star-studded cast including Prabhas, Kriti Sanon, Saif Ali Khan, and Devdutta Nage. However, upon watching the film, it becomes evident that it falls far short of expectations and fails to deliver a satisfying cinematic experience.One of the most glaring issues with "Adipurush" is its visual presentation. Despite being a live-action film, it often feels like a poorly executed animated movie. The special effects and CGI work are subpar, resulting in unrealistic and unconvincing visual sequences. This lackluster visual quality is particularly disappointing considering the film's large budget and the potential for stunning visuals within the context of the Ramayan.Another significant flaw lies in how the film handles the sacred story of the Ramayan. "Adipurush" takes unnecessary liberties with the source material, deviating from the essence and integrity of the epic. The film's screenplay and characterizations fail to capture the depth and complexity of the original tale, resulting in a shallow and superficial interpretation. The narrative lacks the emotional resonance and spiritual depth that make the Ramayan such a timeless and revered story.Furthermore, the performances of the lead actors, despite their talent, fail to make a lasting impression. Prabhas, known for his charismatic presence, feels miscast as Lord Ram, lacking the gravitas and spiritual aura that the character demands. Kriti Sanon's portrayal of Sita lacks depth and fails to capture the strength and resilience of the iconic character. Saif Ali Khan's performance as Ravana, though initially promising, falls victim to weak writing and fails to elevate the character beyond a one-dimensional villain.The pacing of "Adipurush" is uneven, with certain scenes dragging on for too long while others feel rushed and underdeveloped. The lack of cohesive storytelling and the absence of emotional resonance make it difficult to stay engaged throughout the film's runtime.In conclusion, "Adipurush" is a disappointing cinematic experience that fails to do justice to the epic Ramayan. The film's subpar visual effects, misguided interpretation of the source material, and lackluster performances contribute to its overall lack of impact. Fans of the Ramayan and those expecting a grand and faithful adaptation will find themselves sorely let down by this underwhelming rendition.

Direction 1/5
Dialogue 3/5
Saif Ali Khan acting 4/5
Kriti 3/5
Prabhash 2/5.Editing: 2/5.

"ADIPURUSH" is an unfortunate attempt at adapting an epic story, resulting in a cinematic disaster that falls flat on multiple levels. From the onset, it becomes painfully evident that the film has made some regrettable choices in terms of visual effects (VFX), dialogues, and the overall adaptation.Let's start with the VFX, or rather, the lack thereof. The movie's visual effects are nothing short of abysmal. The poorly rendered creatures and unconvincing movement leave the audience cringing with disappointment.Moving on to the dialogues, they prove to be equally disappointing. The use of cheap language, lacking depth and originality. The dialogues fail to evoke any emotional response.However, the most egregious offense committed by "ADIPURUSH" is its degrading adaptation of an epic. The film takes the rich source material and reduces it to a shallow and misguided narrative. The characters are poorly developed, their motivations are unclear, and the plot meanders aimlessly, losing the essence of the original story. It's disheartening to witness such a disregard for the source material, as it alienates fans who were eagerly anticipating a faithful and respectful interpretation.Overall, "ADIPURUSH" is a disappointing cinematic experience that fails on multiple fronts. Its woeful VFX, cringe-worthy dialogues, and degrading adaptation make it a forgettable and regrettable addition to the genre. Save yourself the trouble and seek out better cinematic offerings that do justice to the stories they aim to tell.

This movie is one of the worst I have ever seen. It bears no resemblance to Ramayana. I strongly advise people to listen to or read Valmiki Ramayan, which has no connection whatsoever to this film. Lord Ram doesn't know that Ravana abducted Sita mata until he meets Sugriva and Hanuman.Lanka, which was built by Viswakarma for Ravana's step-brother Khubera, should be depicted as a beautiful place.The fight between Sugriva and Vali occurs twice, and it is in the second attempt that Rama kills Vali, as Vali and Sugriva are twin brothers, Rama finds it difficult to identify Vali.Hanuman recites Ramayan in ashok vatika to establish a dialogue with Sita Mata before revealing himself as Rama's messenger, in order to gain her trust, as he is not a person appointed by Ravana.The list of inaccuracies goes on. Adipurush: A Spectacular Disaster"Adipurush" aims to be an epic tale of mythological proportions, but ends up being a colossal disappointment. With its poorly executed plot and lackluster performances, this film fails to capture the essence of the original story, leaving audiences bewildered and unsatisfied.The visual effects in "Adipurush" are a laughable attempt at grandeur. The CGI feels outdated and tacky, making the mythical creatures and battle sequences appear more comical than awe-inspiring. It's hard to believe that a film made in this era could look so cheap and unconvincing.The lead actors deliver forgettable performances that lack depth and charisma. Their wooden expressions and forced dialogue delivery make it difficult to emotionally connect with the characters or care about their journey. It's as if they were reading lines from a teleprompter without any understanding of the emotions they were supposed to convey.

The movie doesn't even deserve 1 star. Only Prabhas' fans are giving it higher ratings. If you don't believe it is a money grab, just read what Manoj Muntasir said:In an interview with AajTak, Manoj said that the film was heavily inspired by Ramayana. He said in Hindi, "The name of the film is Adipurush. Let me be clear about two things, we have not made Ramayana, we were only inspired by it. Even if you see our disclaimer, we were very clear about it. It would have been easy for us to name the film Ramayana, keeping in mind the marketing strategies. But we knew from the beginning that we are only heavily inspired by the Ramayana, but we are not making Ramayana. We just made a small chunk of the battle fought in the Ramayana."Now, coming to the story, it has a lot of missing characters who play a really important part in the actual story. And most of the characters which are included don't actually play any significant role in this "kalyug's version".Lanka is depicted as a coal mine, even KGF was better than this Lanka which is supposed to be made of gold, hence the phrase, "sone ki Lanka".Dialogues are cringe/utter garbage, actors have no facial expressions/emotions in most of the scenes. I won't go into many details, as I think most of the reviews on social media already cover how bad the dialogues are.Don't waste time and money going to theaters. And if you are planning to take your kids thinking that they will "learn something about our culture/history" you are wrong. You are better off showing them "Ramayana: The Legend of Prince Rama".

Adipurush is a 2023 Indian epic action film that had the potential to be a great adaptation of the Hindu epic Ramayana. However, the film is ultimately a disappointment, thanks to its slow pacing, uneven tone, and lack of emotional depth.The film's performances are all solid, with Prabhas giving a good performance as Rama and Saif Ali Khan giving a more nuanced performance as Ravana. However, the film's supporting cast is largely underutilized, and the film's action sequences are not as exciting as they could have been.The film's biggest problem is its pacing. The first half of the film is slow and ponderous, and the film's tone is uneven, veering between serious and comedic. This makes it difficult to get invested in the story or the characters.The film also lacks emotional depth. The film's battle scenes are exciting, but they lack the emotional impact that they could have had. The film's love story between Rama and Sita is also underdeveloped.Overall, Adipurush is a missed opportunity. The film had the potential to be a great adaptation of the Ramayana, but it is ultimately a disappointment.

The movie Adipurush, a parody of the epic Ramayana, attempts to incorporate its own imaginative elements inspired by Hollywood movies. However, this attempt has backfired, resulting in a disastrous outcome. The Ramayana is not merely a story from Hindu mythology, but a guide for individuals on how to live a good and respectful life. These teachings have been passed down through generations by our parents and grandparents.The epic emphasizes the importance of responsibilities, with the husband being the head of the household and the wife managing the home. It also emphasizes the significance of young people following and respecting their elders. On the other side of the story, Ravana, the king of Lanka, is portrayed as a character who is not a demon but rather overconfident and possesses excessive self-respect. This overconfidence stems from his victories and his devotion to the gods. However, it leads him to become excessively greedy, believing he can do whatever he desires, including capturing and imprisoning women.Ravana's character teaches us the dangers of becoming overconfident in our own success, as it can ultimately lead to a downfall from a high position to a low one. The movie also introduces creative elements such as Ravana forcefully stealing the sky chariot, Pushpaka Viman, from Kubera, which transforms into a demonic bat. However, these additions seem to be attempts to inject Hollywood-inspired imagination into the minds of the audience, but they are received poorly and result in a disaster.I strongly object to this narrative of the great epic Ramayana being turned into a parody. The movie Adipurush fails to capture the essence of the original story and instead presents a distorted version that deviates from the valuable lessons and teachings it imparts.

review_title: A Disastrous Departure from Tradition,total garbage.
review_text:
Adipurush, a highly anticipated movie purportedly based on the Hindu epic Ramayan, falls woefully short of expectations, leaving audiences disappointed and disillusioned. From its misguided choices in visual effects to abysmal dialogues and language inconsistencies, the film misses the mark on multiple levels, resulting in a cinematic experience that can only be described as total garbage.Visual Effects: A Spectacle Gone Wrong
One of the most glaring issues with Adipurush lies in its misguided choices regarding visual effects. Instead of enhancing the storytelling and immersing the viewers in a mythical world, the film's visual effects appear cheap and unconvincing. The lack of attention to detail is evident, as the CGI often looks artificial and fails to create a sense of awe or wonder. This lackluster approach robs the film of its potential to transport audiences into the enchanting realm of Ramayan, leaving them disconnected and unengaged.Abysmal Dialogues: Failing to Inspire
Another major letdown of Adipurush is its woefully written dialogues. The exchanges between characters lack depth, substance, and emotional resonance, reducing pivotal moments in the story to mere shallow interactions. The film fails to capture the essence of the original mythology's profound philosophical and moral teachings, opting instead for trite and uninspiring lines that fail to leave a lasting impact. This absence of compelling dialogue hampers character development and overall narrative progression, leaving the audience yearning for more substance and authenticity.Language Inconsistencies: A Disrespectful Dissonance
Adipurush further compounds its flaws by disregarding the importance of language consistency. In the Hindu epic Ramayan, the characters' manner of speech reflects their personalities, social backgrounds, and cultural contexts. However, in this film, the language inconsistencies are glaring and disrespectful to the source material. Characters who are traditionally depicted as refined and eloquent suddenly resort to colloquialisms and slang, diluting the cultural authenticity and diminishing the impact of their roles. This departure from tradition not only compromises the film's integrity but also demonstrates a lack of respect for the original mythology and has the potential to hurt the religious sentiments of Hindus.Character Transformations: An Appalling Disregard
One of the most distressing aspects of Adipurush is its blatant disregard for retaining the original character personalities. The film drastically transforms Ravan, a Brahmin devotee of Shiv, who is known for his vegetarianism and adherence to strict moral codes. In this adaptation, Ravan's character is completely distorted, betraying the fundamental essence of the mythology. Such an irresponsible portrayal not only disrespects the core values of Hinduism but also undermines the rich cultural heritage that the Ramayan embodies. This departure from tradition leaves audiences questioning the intentions and motivations of the film's creators, who have chosen to deviate from a well-established narrative without valid reason or justification.Conclusion:
Adipurush, touted as a cinematic masterpiece based on the revered Hindu epic Ramayan, disappoints on multiple levels. Its misguided choices in visual effects, abysmal dialogues, language inconsistencies, and appalling character transformations showcase a lack of understanding, respect, and reverence for the source material. This departure from tradition not only robs the film of its potential to enchant and inspire audiences but also has the potential to hurt the religious sentiments of Hindus. Adipurush, in its current form, is an unfortunate example of a promising concept gone horribly wrong, leaving viewers yearning for a faithful and authentic adaptation that pays homage to the timeless and cherished mythology of Ramayan.

review_title: Disappointing and Overhyped: Adipurush Falls Flat
review_text: As an avid moviegoer, I had high hopes for Adipurush, especially with all the buzz surrounding its release. However, after watching it, I can't help but feel utterly let down. Adipurush is a prime example of a film that fails to live up to its enormous hype, and it falls flat in nearly every aspect.First and foremost, the screenplay is an absolute mess. The story lacks coherence and fails to engage the audience from the beginning. The pacing is all over the place, making it difficult to connect with the characters or understand their motivations. It feels like the scriptwriters were more interested in creating visually stunning scenes rather than crafting a compelling narrative.The performances in Adipurush are equally underwhelming. The lead actors deliver lackluster performances, failing to bring depth or emotional resonance to their characters. Their dialogue delivery feels forced and unnatural, making it challenging to empathize with them or invest in their journey. Even seasoned actors seem lost in their roles, unable to salvage the poorly written and developed characters.Another major letdown is the film's visual effects. Considering the massive budget allocated to Adipurush, one would expect cutting-edge special effects and breathtaking action sequences. However, what we get is a subpar display of CGI that looks artificial and unconvincing. The battle scenes lack intensity and fail to generate any excitement or thrill. It's a missed opportunity to create awe-inspiring visuals that could have elevated the movie.Furthermore, the direction and editing leave much to be desired. The director seems unsure of the tone and style of the film, resulting in a disjointed and inconsistent experience. Transitions between scenes are jarring, and the overall flow of the movie feels disjointed and confusing. It's as if the filmmakers were more concerned with style over substance, neglecting the basic principles of storytelling.Ultimately, Adipurush falls short of its lofty expectations. With a weak screenplay, uninspired performances, lackluster visual effects, questionable direction, and forgettable music, it fails to deliver on any front. It's a disappointment for fans who were eagerly awaiting a grand cinematic experience. Save your time and money and opt for other, more deserving films instead.

review_title: Disappointing Departure from Sacred Texts and Mythological Figures
review_text: Adipurush, a highly anticipated film based on sacred texts and books, had the potential to captivate audiences with its retelling of ancient tales. Unfortunately, the movie falls short in various aspects, deviating from the way life has been portrayed in these revered texts. The characters in Adipurush fail to do justice to the actual personalities of the holy figures they represent, leaving audiences feeling disconnected and disappointed.One of the significant disappointments in Adipurush is the portrayal of Hanumanji. A character known for his charisma and wisdom, Hanumanji's portrayal lacks the captivating presence that is expected of him. The dialogues given to this iconic character are wasted, failing to convey the depth and essence of Hanumanji's wisdom and devotion. This missed opportunity to bring out the true charisma of Hanumanji is a major letdown for fans.Another drawback of Adipurush lies in its language. The movie suffers from a lack of clarity in its dialogue delivery, with an excessive use of modern slangs that seem out of place in the ancient setting. This modernization of language undermines the authenticity of the film and creates a jarring contrast between the setting and the dialogue. It would have been more appropriate to use language that resonates with the historical period being depicted.Moreover, the characters of Ram and Ravan, central figures in the epic tale, are portrayed in a manner that deviates significantly from their well-known personalities. The film fails to capture the essence of these characters, resulting in a lack of emotional connection between the audience and the protagonists. The portrayal of Ram and Ravan lacks the complexity and depth that make them such compelling figures in mythology.Furthermore, Adipurush fails to evoke the feeling of a kingdom for either Ram or Ravan. The grandeur and magnificence that are synonymous with these characters' reigns are missing, leaving the audience without a true sense of the power and glory that they once possessed. The lack of attention to this crucial aspect detracts from the overall immersive experience of the film.One of the most disappointing aspects of Adipurush is its excessive reliance on Western animation and models. Rather than creating a unique visual style that pays homage to the source material, the movie feels like a sluggish copy of some cheap Hollywood production. This over-adaptation of Western influences diminishes the originality and distinctiveness that could have been achieved, resulting in a lackluster cinematic experience.In conclusion, Adipurush fails to live up to the expectations set by its source material. The movie's departure from the way life has been portrayed in sacred texts and books is a major letdown, leaving fans feeling disconnected. The characters in the film, including Hanumanji, lack the charisma and depth that they should possess, and the use of modern slangs in the dialogue further undermines the film's authenticity. Additionally, the portrayal of Ram and Ravan is inconsistent with their true personalities, and the film fails to evoke the grandeur and kingdom associated with these figures. The excessive adaptation of Western animation and models only adds to the disappointment, making Adipurush feel like a lackluster imitation of a cheap Hollywood movie. Overall, Adipurush falls short in its execution and fails to deliver a captivating cinematic experience.

It felt unnecessary and disrespectful, as it deviated from the authentic essence of our religion and its beliefs. It is disheartening to see our sacred stories presented in a sensationalized and misinterpreted manner, which can perpetuate misunderstandings and hurt sentiments.I believe the movie missed an opportunity to explore the profound teachings and values of our religion. Instead, it seemed to prioritize shock value and cheap thrills, detracting from the meaningful messages that could have been conveyed.I hope that future films will take a more thoughtful approach when representing religious narratives and foster greater understanding and respect. As an audience, we deserve narratives that genuinely reflect the depth and significance of our beliefs.

review_text: Adipurush, touted as an epic retelling of the Ramayana, turns out to be an absolute disappointment that utterly fails to capture the essence and grandeur of the ancient epic. From its cringe-worthy bat dialogs to its questionable casting choices and misrepresentations of the Ramayana, this film is a colossal letdown.Let's start with the bat dialogs. It's mind-boggling how the filmmakers thought it would be a good idea to include such juvenile and ridiculous dialogues in a supposedly epic movie. The usage of modern slang and language completely undermines the authenticity and reverence that should have been accorded to the Ramayana. It feels like the writers were more interested in pandering to a younger audience rather than treating the source material with respect.Next comes the casting, which is nothing short of a disaster. While Prabhas may be a popular actor, he is woefully miscast as Lord Rama. His portrayal lacks the depth, charisma, and regal aura that one would expect from the legendary character. The casting decision feels more like a marketing gimmick aimed at capitalizing on Prabhas' star power rather than a thoughtful choice to bring the character of Lord Rama to life.The misrepresentation of the Ramayana is perhaps the most egregious offense committed by Adipurush. The filmmakers have taken significant liberties with the original story, distorting key elements and diluting its cultural and spiritual significance. The epic is a revered and cherished part of Indian heritage, and it deserved a faithful adaptation that respects its core values and teachings. Instead, Adipurush presents a watered-down version that does a disservice to the original text and its followers.Moreover, the film fails to create a cohesive narrative and struggles to maintain a consistent tone. The pacing feels uneven, with unnecessary deviations and subplots that add nothing substantial to the overall story. This lack of focus undermines the emotional impact and fails to capture the epic scale and timeless appeal of the Ramayana.In terms of visual effects and production design, Adipurush falls short of expectations as well. The CGI feels artificial and unconvincing, failing to create a seamless blend between the real and the mythical worlds. The film's set designs lack the grandeur and attention to detail that would have brought the ancient era to life. It feels like a missed opportunity to create a visually stunning and immersive experience.All in all, Adipurush is a misfire on multiple fronts. Its bat dialogs, questionable casting choices, and misrepresentations of the Ramayana leave a bitter taste in the mouths of those who were eagerly anticipating a faithful and awe-inspiring retelling of the epic. It's a disservice to the rich cultural heritage it claims to represent and an example of how not to adapt a beloved story. Save your time and seek out other adaptations that do justice to the epic tale of the Ramayana.

review_title: Sanatan tradition has been indiscriminately displayed
review_text:
Manoj Muntashir what the hell u have made .....?Can't have worst depiction of holy ramayana than this movie Out of Context and Derogatory dialoguesAdipurush is merely a Bollywood-ised version of one of the most epic tales that ever existed. If you keep the story aside for it's largely known to all, the execution turns out to be a messy blend of over-the-top CGI and passable VFX, and making it worse are the intentionally funny dialogues that sound misplaced in a sensitive and mythological story. Why would you want Hanuman to say 'Jalegi tere baap ki'?"Better to watch the ancient Ramayana rather then wasting time on this so called Epic.

I cannot even begin to express my absolute rage and frustration after enduring the mind-numbing disaster that is "An Agonizing Journey." This abysmal excuse for a film not only wasted my precious time but also managed to insult my intelligence with its sheer incompetence.From the very start, it became painfully clear that the filmmakers had no idea how to construct a coherent and engaging narrative. The plot stumbled aimlessly from one scene to another, lacking any semblance of structure or purpose. It was a chaotic mess that left me questioning why I bothered to invest even a moment of my life in this drivel.If the abhorrent storytelling wasn't enough to enrage me, the agonizingly slow pace pushed me to the brink of insanity. Each scene dragged on for an eternity, as if the filmmakers took pleasure in torturing their audience. I couldn't help but wonder if they had a bet going on who could create the most unbearable cinematic experience. Congratulations, you won!The characters in this cinematic catastrophe were as lifeless as a corpse in a morgue. Their motivations were vague and their actions inexplicable. I felt zero connection or empathy towards any of them, as they stumbled through the film like clueless puppets. It was a baffling display of lazy writing and uninspired performances that left me seething with anger.Let's not forget the technical aspects, or should I say lack thereof. The cinematography was a disgrace, featuring unimaginative shots and a complete disregard for visual storytelling. It was as if the cameraperson had fallen asleep and accidentally pressed record. And don't even get me started on the drab color grading and forgettable soundtrack. It was a cacophony of mediocrity that assaulted my senses.To call this film "regional" would be an insult to regional cinema. It failed to capture any essence of its supposed cultural backdrop, reducing it to a laughable backdrop devoid of authenticity. It was a slap in the face to the rich tapestry of regional storytelling, and I resent the filmmakers for their blatant disregard.The most infuriating aspect of this whole ordeal was the complete lack of emotional impact. I went into this film hoping to be moved, to be touched by the human experience. Instead, I was left cold and empty, with no trace of the promised emotional journey. It was an insult to my emotions and a blatant waste of my time.In conclusion, "An Agonizing Journey" is a shameful testament to the incompetence of its creators. It is a prime example of everything that can go wrong in filmmaking. From the haphazard storytelling to the lifeless characters and the technical disaster, this film fails on every possible level. I urge you, fellow moviegoers, to spare yourself the agony and avoid this abomination at all costs.

The audience is left struggling to connect the dots and make sense of the story, which ultimately hampers their overall engagement and enjoyment.The visual effects in Adipurash are another letdown. Given the grand scale of the mythological world it aims to portray, one would expect top-notch CGI and stunning visuals. Unfortunately, the execution falls flat, with glaring inconsistencies and poorly rendered sequences that fail to transport the audience into the fantastical realm. The subpar visual effects become a constant distraction and undermine the overall immersion, making it difficult to suspend disbelief.

review_title: ADIPURUSH: Tarnishing the expectation of Indian Mythology Lovers
review_text: Let me start with something positive. Movie started with a good note and "Ram Siya Ram" song gave spiritual pleasure to our ears. Background music and Songs of the movie were really good. But apart from that if I have to say anything about the movie, I must say that makers failed to do their homework while making this epic. Even if we will keep sentiments aside on the name of cinematic liberty, the makers made me feel that they dnt understand cinema. The screenplay is very poor and the dark theme of movie made us feel that we are watching Game of Thrones not Ramayan. Makers made us feel that during Banawaas time of Lord Ram, Surya Dev also went on exile. VFX, CGI and other visual effects were very poor which forced us to think where they have spent 550 crore. Was that even the real budget of the movie or just some Random numbers were given to create hype. Movie makers need to understand that in big budget movie, if money is being spent on paying the fee of movie stars then we cant make a good cinema. Good cinema can only be made if budget is being spent more on VFX, Dialogue writing, CGI etc. And less on paying fee of actors.Talking about actors the selection of Case were horrible. No offence to Prabhas obviously he is one of the biggest star of the Country but he don't look like Lord Ram from any angle. Off course the beauty of Kriti Sanon is exceptional but for Goddess Sita we need beauty plus someone who is having Indian Look. Extra sharp feature of Kriti failing her to look like Sita. Selecting Saif as Ravana is perhaps biggest selection disaster of history of movie Industry. O n top of that giving him Khilji like look just poured Ghee in the Fire. In my opinion if they would have selected Rajat Tokas as Lord Ram and Shweta Basu Prasad as Mata Sita, that would have been perfect selection. These two are not less than anyone when it comes to acting and also they would not have charged like Prabhas and Kriti. That money could have been spent on VFX, CGI and other Visuals so that at least we would have got some visual treat.If I have to talk about performances, Kriti somewhere did justice with Sita Mata character. But she couldn't able to do much because of her limited presence on Screen. Prabhas tried his best. He even did justice of his star power but he miserable failed to made us feel the presence of Lord Ram on big screen. His flat expression throughout the movie has made the things even worst and we couldn't able to connect ourselves from the movie. About Saif as Ravan, I literally have no words. Trailer made me feel that he must have done good performance wise but witnessing him in this character on big screen was most horrible part of the movie. If we will try to ignore his looks and appearance on the name of Cinematic Liberty, his performance made things even more worse. He was walking like a thanos and his dialogue delivery was soo poor that his presence on screen was causing irritation.At last I will only say , please keep yourself away from Adipurush. If you want to show story of Lord Ram to your children, better to go with 'Ramayan of Ramananda Sager'or even Japanese Cartoon movie 'The Legend of Prince Ram'.

review_title: The whole film is a collection of failed experiments. Parents please dont show this to your kids as Epic Ramayan.
review_text:
Adipurush is Poor filmmaking example. The whole film is a collection of failed experiments.Parents please don't show this to your kids as Epic Ramayan if they are watching Ramayan for first time. This is really very misleading film.All 7 elements of Film failed : Setting, Conflict, Character, Dialogue, Theme, Plot, and Climax.1) Setting: 1/10: When attempting to incorporate a renowned epic into one's own imaginary universe, one must exercise extreme caution. Looks like some immature kids work.>>>No army of the dead existed under Ravan. It was a mockery, to see the skullman army.>>>Another mistake was making Lanka look like a dark, black castle . Lanka is a beautiful green place.>>>VFX Overdone : Instead of a handful, the screen was completely covered with peacocks, deers, and birds in several scenes. How could such a basic thing go unnoticed? It looked so cluttered.>>> Planet of Apes movie copied for Vanar Sena.>>> What a mess done with pushpak viman . Why why why extreme experiment and that also game of thrones as is copy no innovation.>>>That's a terribly dumb thing to do. As an alternative to jewellery, Sita's necklace single pearl is used for her tracing.2) Conflict : 1/10 : The scene where they teased Raghav about Sita's death was very silly. That didn't help show how angry Raghav was. Instead, it made Ravan look stupid.3) Character: 0/10 : Movie didn't do a good job of establishing Characters. Not good at all. Very bad casting .>>> Its known that Raghav was from Ayodhya and Ravan was from Lanka, it should have made sense that they looked like Natives.>>>Ravan looked liked more of Aryan than a Lanka native. Anyone who has watched Game of Thrones will know its as is copy of John Snow.>>>Laxman such an innocent face. No aggressiveness.>>>Sita is admired and respected as a graceful strong woman. The way the actress acted didn't do justice to Sita's role. She looked very stupid and fragile. In a scene where Hanuman does something funny, her response seems so foolish given the role she is in. Her dressing was copied from some old Nal Damyanti paintings and similar goose were seen in some scenes.>>>Raghav and Jaanki's connection could not be strengthened via songs too. It would have been more effective to show Jaanki and Raghav trekking through woods, enduring difficulties, and cooking and eating together rather than showing them in a glamorous setting surrounded by sunflower fields.>>> No connect between Raghav and Hanuman
Then Surpankha, Mandodari, Vibhishan. Meghnath - was the industry lack of people none of them fit the role. I will say TV serials which have made Ramayan did better casting.None of the Characters met the expectations of the role.4) Dialogue : 0/10: who approved dialogues even if writer wrote that stuff. As a team all failed.5/6) Theme/Plot: Negative points as film did blunder with the Epic Ramayan. Every possible mistake can be witnessed in this movie .7) Climax : what a bad ending ... audience who was sitting for 3 hrs need to absorb the emotions at end . However with the film which failed to engage from beginning what could be expected at end.---------
2 things which can be appreciated.1) Shiv upasana done by Ravan beautiful work.2) Raghav killing Vali, and it was clear why he had to shoot Vali from behind.

review_title: "Visually Struggling 'Adipurush' Misses the Mark: A Mythological Epic Hindered by Shoddy Visual Effects"
review_text: "Adipurush," the new Indian mythological action-fantasy film, presents a familiar tale with a star-studded cast, including Prabhas in the lead role. The movie's ambition to adapt elements from The Ramayana while bringing larger-than-life Hindu gods and epic battles to the screen is evident. However, it struggles to rise above its visual shortcomings, particularly its subpar and distractingly artificial special effects.The narrative revolves around the courageous hero Raghava (Prabhas), also known as Ram, who sets out to rescue his kidnapped wife Sita (Kriti Sanon) from the clutches of the evil multi-headed god Lankesh/Ravana (Saif Ali Khan). The film's title, "Adipurush," meaning "First Man" in Sanskrit, hints at its mythological themes and the grandeur it aspires to achieve.Unfortunately, the film's visual effects undermine its potential greatness. The amateurish and unconvincing computer-generated imagery detracts from the immersive experience, making the first part of the film feel tedious and uninspiring. Despite the high budget, the shoddy green-screen compositing and poorly-rendered elements overshadow the otherwise captivating narrative.Prabhas' charismatic presence and his initial confrontation with demonic wraiths offer moments of excitement, but the film's technical shortcomings become increasingly evident as the story unfolds. The scenes involving Sita and Raghava's romantic moments encircled by poorly-executed pink flamingos exemplify the film's struggle to create a believable world.Additionally, the musical numbers, particularly those involving Sita and Lankesh, suffer from lackluster visuals and fail to generate the desired emotional impact. The film's poetic song lyrics and expository dialogue often come across as forced and contrived. The characters' movements often serve to highlight the deficiencies of the computer-generated graphics, diminishing the overall quality of the film.Despite its derivative nature, borrowing elements from popular series like "Game of Thrones" and "Lord of the Rings," as well as the "Baahubali" films, "Adipurush" manages to salvage some dramatic tension in its concluding battles. The showdown between Raghava, his brother Sesh/Laxmana, and the formidable Lankesh and his second-in-command Indrajit provides a narrow focus that delivers sporadic moments of engagement.Director Om Raut, known for his work on "Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior," attempts to infuse the film with grandeur, particularly in its climactic battle scenes. Yet, even as the film gradually escalates towards its finale, the subpar visual effects persist, inhibiting the realization of its full potential.In the end, "Adipurush" grapples with the paradox of aiming for epic proportions while being hindered by its own technical limitations. While the film's cast and its ambitious narrative offer glimpses of promise, its glaring visual flaws and lack of visual finesse ultimately prevent it from achieving the grand cinematic spectacle it aspires to be. I would rate the film a 5/10 due to its disappointing visual execution and missed opportunities to create a truly immersive mythological experience.

review_title: This is how you presented our religioin.
review_text:
First and foremost, the plot is a convoluted mess. It jumps around without any clear direction or coherence, making it impossible to invest in the story or connect with the characters. The filmmakers seem to have thrown random ideas together without any consideration for storytelling or logical progression. It's as if they relied on a series of poorly written clichés to pass as a narrative. The characters are equally abysmal. They lack depth, development, or any redeeming qualities that would make them remotely interesting. The performances are wooden and uninspired, further exacerbating the problem. It's almost painful to watch these actors struggle with the poorly written dialogue, as if they themselves realize how awful the movie is.

"Adipurush" stands as a grave disappointment, offering one of the worst representations of the epic Ramayana that I have seen to date. The mischaracterizations, sloppy storyline, and inaccurate representations make for a film that does not do justice to the epic it attempts to retell.The leading actor's portrayal of the principal character is lackluster and fails to capture the essence of the role. This discrepancy is evident in every frame, making the performance not just forgettable but also deeply frustrating.However, the greatest fault of "Adipurush" lies in its depiction of Ravan and his ethnicity. Traditionally known as dark-skinned Rakshashas, the portrayal of Ravan as a light-skinned Northerner is a considerable misrepresentation that undermines the rich diversity of our epics. This inaccurate depiction feels like a forced attempt to align the characters of Ravan and Ram, which doesn't resonate with the epic's true spirit.Despite these glaring issues, Saif Ali Khan's performance is a silver lining. He delivers a strong portrayal and proves his mettle as an actor. But, his casting as Ravan feels misplaced; given his strong performance, he would have been better suited for the roles of Ram or Hanuman.The narrative of "Adipurush" is equally disappointing. The storyline is sloppy and riddled with plot inconsistencies, creating an experience that is more confusing than engaging.In conclusion, "Adipurush" is a poor adaptation that fails on multiple fronts. It misrepresents the characters of the Ramayana and fails to deliver a coherent and engaging storyline. Despite Saif Ali Khan's commendable performance, the film remains a cinematic misfire. It serves as a grim reminder of the responsibility that comes with adapting beloved epics. We can only hope that future attempts will be more considerate and accurate in their portrayals.

The careless depiction in "Adipirush" not only failed to respect the core values and practices of Hinduism but also missed an opportunity to promote harmony and empathy among diverse religious communities. It is my hope that future filmmakers approach Hindu themes with greater sensitivity and strive for authentic portrayals that foster understanding and respect.

review_title: It is terrible, and not because of the VFX or the dialogues
review_text: I gave this movie a chance because somewhere I felt it was a vision that Om Raut had and the audience did not accept it. But , man was I wrong... The film is a hot mess right from the beginning where they set up an action sequence to introduce Ram, I have no problem if your idea is to show the yudha kaanda in a commercial, marvel style presentation. But what are those demons? Who are they, why are they there, why was Rama fighting them??? Just pure lazy writing....Secondly, why is Lakshman/Sesh just there? Instead of Ram being a brother / uttamapurush teaching him morals, he just comes out as an annoying character with that stone face expression in the first half before saying something and Ram correcting him. And in the second half of the film just being there for the sanjeevani sequence...There is no real emotional connection with any of the characters, except for the part where Ram and Hanuman meet for the first time. And Sita, omg, why is she there to only say a few mass dialogues to Ravana every 10 mins.... That is all she does in the film. A pure commercial film heroine.They failed to create a connection with Jatayu, Sugreev even Ram... They just tell you that he's a man of honor, with no embodiment in the characters.I'm okay with modernizing the characters and all. And willing to excuse the poor art direction and VFX, if they were sincere in making a good movie. But this genuinely feels like a rushed , commercial product with the idea being make "money with action". Even then, the action sequences are awfully choreographed too....

review_title: Big Question on Big Budget movie and
review_text: The movie in question suffers from several notable flaws. Firstly, the CGI effects fail to deliver a sense of immersion and fall short of expectations. The dialogue presentation is also lackluster, lacking depth and failing to engage the audience effectively. Moreover, the storyline feels unoriginal, drawing heavily from other well-known series, which hampers its ability to offer a unique and captivating narrative.It is important to address a factual inaccuracy within the film as well. The claim that Sita, a character in the movie, belongs to Nepal rather than India is historically accurate. Nepal has its own distinct cultural heritage, and it was never a part of India.Overall, these shortcomings in CGI effects, dialogue presentation, and originality of the storyline detract from the movie's overall quality. Viewers seeking a more engaging and authentic cinematic experience may find themselves disappointed. It is advisable to approach this film with lowered expectations and consider exploring alternative options that better meet your preferences.

review_title: We need not copy the Western movies to make the greatest epic of all time a hit.
review_text: Firstly beginning with the opening scene...why do we need dementors from Harry Potter?? Wouldn't it be better to see the opening scene as the day before Lord Ram's coronation and how the next day he instead has to go for vanvas. I wanted to see the opulence and grandeur of Lanka, not a dark and gloomy Mordor with orcs.The movie lacked a strong background narrative in most required scenarios like Shabari, Jatayu,Mandodari, ,Meganad, Jamvat,Lord Hanuman etc. The emotional connect was truly lost. The epic has such strong characters emotions and not a milligram of them conveyed through the movie. Lord Hanuman who is known for his perfect grammar, speech and the Lord of 8 siddhis ( superpowers) cannot say road side slang ...please. He has the power to be as small as an atom , to grow has heavy as a mountain and so on an so forth.Ravan was a Brahma gyani one who has knowledge of the universe. An engineer, music maestro,Astrology, Ayurveda, inventor of Veena and other 55 qualities. He had 11 airports and please didn't need a weird bat with dragon voice from Game of thrones to fly around. His viman ( plane) worked on voice recognition system .It was an epic battle between two supermassive supreme beings. And very humbly Lord Ram brought Ravan to his knees and broke his pride.I would suggest one rather watch The Legends of Ramayan by Amish on Discovery plus. So beautifully explained with true locations and deep insight.Lastly when you are making a movie on Lord Ram , do not be afraid to say Jai Shri Ram , Jai Hanuman 🙏. Ram the name that contains the universe.

review_title: Nothing more than a futile attempt to exploit Hindu faith - Adipurush is offensive and non serious.
review_text: Adipurush is not only one of the worst cinematic adaptations of Ramayan ever made, but also a shoddy, and offensive treatment to the parent chronicle of Lord Ramchandra's pastimes in Ayodhya and His 14 years long exile.There is not a single character that has been seriously presented. The movie makers intention was probably to mock the entire gravity and seriousness of this epic. Dialogues are offensive. I was shocked by what was playing on the screen. What made the makers think that such a non-serious and in fact insulting attempt would be lauded? The sheer assumption that the audience was so uninformed about "Ramayan" as a text is appalling.Om Raut needs to be introspect of what he has done with the source material like that of Valmikiji's timeless epic, Ramayan. He has completed done away with its "dharmik" essence. No research has been done or at least that is what it looks like. The screenplay is discontinuous and uninteresting. It alters significant events from the Ramayan without any plausible reason. The scenes do not register gracefully. There is legit no emotional connect for characters. Actions scenes have directly been picked up from Hollywood movies. The performances are mediocre to poor, mostly tending towards the latter. One is forced to wonder where did the 700 crores go? What was going on in the minds of the makers when they were writing and directing such a movie? How did the actors agree to be a part of this futile effort for an adaptation? They had the audacity to call this hostile adaptation a "work of devotion"? Seriously?The lesser is said about other aspects of the movie the better. I already feel like I need to cleanse my eyes after the mess that I watched. Adipurush appears to be a work of hostility and planned insult to Lord Ram and His pastimes. Sadly, the makers of the film (Director Om Raut and writer Manoj Muntashir) promoted it as some monumental effort to glorify Lord Ram. At least, it doesn't come across as that.

There should be option of giving negative review too.Anyways I will like to give a genuine feedback about this movie: Stupid storytelling way, Manoj Munatoshir should take half responsibility of this disaster and then whosoever responsible for casting in the movie. Prabhas can never be portrayed as Ram, he can be Bhima or duryodhan if someone will make Mahabharat in future. Every time he appears on screen as Shri Ram it disappoints! We have loved Prabhas in his earlier characters like superhero but this time a big No !!!This movie should be banned as it's hurting sentiments of hindu.Kirti Sanon is still good in her character.

review_title: Disgracing Hindu Scriptures: A Disappointing Film
review_text: Adipurush, a Bollywood adaptation of the revered Ramayana, is a profound insult to Hindu scriptures. This film disappoints on every level, disrespecting the essence of the source material and tarnishing the heritage it represents.The casting choices are a major letdown. Saif Ali Khan's portrayal of Ravan lacks the larger-than-life presence the character demands, with a laughable hairstyle and pathetic costumes. Kriti Sanon fails to capture the essence of Sita Mata, while Prabhas' portrayal of Lord Ram is a disgrace, lacking the nobility and composure associated with the revered figure.Director Om Raut's ineptitude is evident, with poor direction, a lackluster screenplay, and cringe-worthy dialogues. The film's exorbitant budget is wasted on subpar VFX and graphics that would be better suited to a high school project.Adipurush not only defames the history of India and Maryada Purushottam Shri Ram but also showcases a shocking level of depravity. The filmmakers insult the holy Ramayana and its characters, with no respect for the cultural values they represent.I urge all Hindus to boycott this movie, as it distorts our mythology and insults our scriptures. Adipurush is a disgraceful attempt at storytelling that should be avoided. Instead, turn to the authentic glory of the Ramayana in its original texts.

review_title: Baseless, Technical errors, Ramayana from another planet
review_text: Aadipurush, the much-anticipated mythological epic, falls flat on its face, leaving audiences with a sense of profound disappointment and dissatisfaction. Directed by a renowned filmmaker, one would expect a masterpiece that transcends boundaries and delivers an immersive experience. Unfortunately, this film fails to live up to even the most basic expectations, making it one of the worst movies of 2023.One of the most glaring issues with Aadipurush is its lackluster execution. Despite its ambitious premise, the film fails to create a captivating mythological world. The production design feels uninspired and lacks attention to detail. The sets and costumes appear generic and fail to transport viewers into the mythical era they are meant to represent. The visual effects, touted as one of the film's strengths, are underwhelming, with poorly rendered CGI that often takes viewers out of the experience rather than enhancing it.The performances in Aadipurush are equally disappointing. Prabhas, in the role of Lord Rama, delivers a wooden and uninspiring portrayal. His lack of emotional depth and charisma make it difficult to connect with his character, leaving a void at the center of the narrative. Saif Ali Khan's Ravana, touted as a revelation, is nothing more than a caricature of evil, lacking the complexity and depth needed to make the character truly memorable. The chemistry between the leads is non-existent, and their encounters feel forced and devoid of any genuine emotion.The screenplay of Aadipurush fails to bring anything new or thought-provoking to the table. It follows a predictable narrative trajectory that offers no surprises or innovative twists. The dialogue is often trite and lacks impact, failing to leave a lasting impression. Additionally, the film suffers from pacing issues, with several scenes feeling unnecessarily dragged out, resulting in a bloated runtime that tests the audience's patience.While mythological films often have the potential to explore timeless themes and provide social commentary, Aadipurush falls short in this regard. It fails to offer any fresh perspective or relevance to the contemporary world, making the narrative feel hollow and disconnected from the audience's reality. The film relies too heavily on the familiarity of the source material, assuming that the audience's prior knowledge will fill in the gaps and compensate for the lack of depth in the storytelling.Moreover, Aadipurush suffers from poor editing choices. There are jarring cuts between scenes, disrupting the flow and coherence of the narrative. The film lacks a strong editorial hand, resulting in a disjointed experience that feels like a collection of loosely connected scenes rather than a cohesive story.In conclusion, Aadipurush is a colossal disappointment and unquestionably one of the worst movies of 2023. Its lackluster execution, uninspired production design, and underwhelming performances make it a forgettable addition to the genre of mythological epics. The film fails to deliver on its promise of a grand cinematic experience and falls short in every aspect that matters: storytelling, visuals, performances, and emotional engagement.As audiences, we deserve better than Aadipurush. It serves as a cautionary tale of how even the most promising projects can go astray when not executed with care and creativity. This film will only leave viewers longing for a more compelling and imaginative retelling of the mythological tale it attempts to portray. It is best to avoid Aadipurush and seek out other cinematic experiences that truly resonate and leave a lasting impact.

"Adipurush" had the potential to bring the epic Ramayana to life, but unfortunately, it falls short of expectations. The portrayal of Lord Hanuman with roadside-style dialogues and the underutilization of Lord Laxman leave much to be desired. Prabhas' performance as Lord Ram lacks expression and emotional depth. However, Saif Ali Khan stands out as a convincing Raavan, while Kriti Sanon's limited screen time hampers her portrayal of Sita. The visual effects appear cartoonish, and the soundtrack fails to evoke the necessary emotions. Overall, "Adipurush" fails to capture the emotional resonance and character depth of the Ramayana, making it a disappointing adaptation.
