review_title: A lazy version of Ramayana critiqued by a Hindu (closet ashiest)
review_text: I am a Hindu who grew up in India. Most people know about Ramayana thanks to an epic serial made in late 80s by Ramanand Sagar. Additionally, Ramayana is part of lots of people growing up in North India thanks to Ramleela. Ramleela is street theater that takes place a week before Dusherra (20 days before diwali) on street corners everywhere in North India. Ramleela depicts the story of Ramayana and each production takes their take depending on their budget and talent. I say this because I don't have any problem with producer Om Raut making their own artistic version. My problem is that his version is a lazy version where artistic liberties are taken and replaced with heavy dose of plagiarism or plain thoughtlessness.Let's start with dialogues. In the guise of being modern and relevant we have some really thoughtless words uttered by characters who would never speak in that manner.Editing and pacing of movie is slow and almost makes you go to sleep. There are just way too many slow motion shots and there is absolutely nothing natural about what you see.CGI is used extensively in this movie but unfortunately it is of very poor quality. You feel like you are watching and animation movie at all times.Lot of side characters are just lifted from western movies. Vanar Sena (Monkey army) looks like is lifted directly from planet of Apes. Ravana is desired to be shown bigger than others and that makes him looks he is floating and look they are trying to copy Thanos with a buzz cut. Asuras in lanka looks to be lifted directly from Orcs in Lord of the rings. Lanka is a direct copy of Asgard from Thor. Ravana looks to be riding the dragon from Game of Thrones.Thoughfulness and artistry is lacking and it instead is replaced by borrowed CGI and whole lot of nothing. Even though I am not religious it looks this was a huge waste of money and opportunity.

This movie is an epic fail at capturing the true essence and spirit of the great Ramayana. The integrity, divinity, aesthetics and beauty of the characters and the revered scripture have been reduced to a mockery. I really don't know what the makers and especially the director was thinking while making such a disaster. There are plenty of sources for reference be it in Telugu film industry, Hindi film industry, Ramayana by Ramanand sagar or any anime or cartoon shows. They all have been legendary and have done an exemplary and sincere job at capturing the true beauty of Ramayana. Here, the scripture has been completely distorted for fulfilling the whims and fancies of the director. Too much creative liberty must not be attempted in historical and mythological projects as it makes the credibility of the entire film questionable which was the case in this film. The trailer itself was disappointing. The dialogues are absolutely horrible, making it too casual and slang filled for a divine project. In many of the dialogues even the original references and meanings have been distorted. Costumes, settings, Vfx nothing is up to the mark. Extremely disappointing. Even the actors' potential was not used to its fullest. Please avoid this movie! Its a waste of time. This is the worst portrayal of Ramayana ever in India.

review_title: Destroyed the reality of Indian History
review_text: This is one of the most disgusting adaption of a story with great religious & historical importance.I guess the main intention of this movie was only to convert all the illegally earned money by the director/producers into legal investment & declare loss to avoid paying taxes.Can't blame the actors for this abomination. They tried to play their roles in the best way possible. Hence the 2 star that I've given. It's only the crew who has to be blamed for this.Feels like the entire movie has been shot inside a bedroom or a small hall & to that the most pathetic & disgusting CGI is added. It costed ISRO 450cr for the Mangalyaan mission which benefited India & the scientists in its studies for about 10-15 years. This movie costing 600cr couldn't even have proper CGI. The 1987 Ramayana television series had better CGI than this.Why rename the three leads, i.e. Ram, Sita & Laksmana while the names of the rest of the characters remain the same/original.The Dialogues.... Oh My God!!! How did the CBFC approve this movie with such rubbish dialogues. It's More like a third grade standard less movie dialogues.To be honest there are much better historical adoptions made in a much better & economical way. The 1992 Japanese adoption of Ramayana had been produced & directed in the most respectable manner.Guys, please don't spend your valuable money on this so called movie. It's an insult to the movie industry. Save it so that you can spend on a different & more valuable movie. I could barely keep my eyes open for half the movie and I forced myself out of the theatre.I don't know what is wrong with Indian Cinema. The quality of its content is deteriorating movie by movie. Just adding big names to the cast list is not going to make the movie a success. Proper direction, screenplay, production, dialogues, etc, all contributes to a movies success. Most of the historically important stories are being adopted & portrayed in a wrong way or by the wrong cast.

review_title: WHAT's A BETTER WORD FOR WORST?
review_text: Well, today I finally watched the most anticipated movie, 'Adipurush.' I have been following many pages where it was said that this movie would give 'JAWAN' a good competition. However, I am sorry to say that this movie didn't live up to anyone's expectations.First of all, let's talk about the plot. You will see Amrendra Bahubali as Ram, delivering dialogues that are relatively similar to what he gave in 'Bahubali.' Then there's Kriti Sanon, portrayed as a super hot Satyug Kanya, whom we'll be calling 'Mata Sita.' There's a mute Laxman and a Hanuman who speaks Tapori language. The only pro factor in the movie is Ravana, played by Saif Ali Khan, and his role was well-acted, but unfortunately, our lovely director sabotaged it with excessive VFX. Kudos to him.Now, let's talk about the cinematography and animations of the movie. I think Bengali cartoons like 'Teni Da' have better animations than this movie. The movie relies heavily on animations, and even Indrajit, Ravana's son, has super vamp speed powers. It's like they knew they would be sharing the screen with Flash, so they gave him such powers. The animated Vanara, bats, and demons all had fake effects. None of them felt real. Even BHERIA MOVIE had better animations than these characters.Moving on to the dialogue, a mythological movie based on different mythological books was given poor dialogues. From Prabhas' portrayal of Ram, who doesn't sound anything like Maryada Purshottam, to Hanuman and Indrajit speaking in Tapori language. Even Sita's conversation with Ravana was quite disrespectful, as people in Satyug do not use words like 'tu' and 'chal.' Maybe the whole budget was spent on making nasty animations, which is why they couldn't hire someone to write Sanskrit lyrics for the movie.Finally, let's discuss the storyline. The challenge and advantage of making a mythological movie is that people already have an idea of the script. Those who have read the Vedas know what happened according to them, and those who know the story of Ramayana from cartoons or web series also have some idea. The script for such a movie should be clear, and the difficult part should be deciding what to show and what to omit from the story that people already know. You cannot manipulate the narrative that has been studied in the Vedas for years, but this movie has done just that. It has changed the perspective of what we were shown in Ramayan since our childhood days.I mean, where was it mentioned that Hanuman brought the entire mountain of Sanjeevani just because he thought it would be needed in the future? Or where was it shown that Laxman bathed in Sanjeevani water? Or that Ravana used a giant bat? Or that Ram and Laxman actually witnessed Ravana abducting Mata Sita and were chasing him to save her? I have no idea where the director found these stories. Where were these stories in Ramayana by Ramanand Sagar, or 'Siya Ke Ram' on Star Plus, or the cartoon Ramayan? I haven't read Valmiki's Ramayan, but I did read 'The Forest of Enchantment,' which is Sita's version of Ramayan.Did they happen to miss these details in the Ramayan which I have seen or read?I am confused!Furthermore, Sita should always be portrayed as a woman with dignity and self-respect. A TRUE FEMINIST. She is obviously beautiful, but that portrayal is missing here.Now I am convinced that BHRAMASTRA was a better movie with annoying dialogue SHIVA SHIVA SHIVA and a better VFX.

I just witnessed the most colossal disappointment ever.This movie was an absolute train wreck from start to finish. The writing, the VFX, everything was pure garbage.The only redeeming quality was the music. Everything else was an unfunny joke. The dialogue was cringe-worthy, and the costume designing was a complete disaster.I'VE NEVER FELT THIS LET DOWN BY A MOVIE BEFORE.The dialogue writing, in particular, was shockingly disrespectful, and it's a flaw that cannot be easily overlooked or forgiven.I find it difficult to comprehend how anyone could have approved of such a production.This film will be remembered for generations as an example of how a movie should not be made, a cautionary tale in the realm of filmmaking.

review_title: A Missed Opportunity - Review by Kalyug Briefs
review_text: Film Review: Adipurush (2023) - A Missed Opportunity - Review by Kalyug BriefsAdipurush, a highly anticipated film based on the epic Ramayana, falls short of expectations, leaving audiences disappointed. Despite the potential to showcase divine miracles and captivate viewers with stunning special effects, the film fails to make maximum use of 3D animation and visual effects, ultimately diluting the grandeur of the Indian epic.One of the main issues with Adipurush is the missed opportunity to fully exploit the rich source material. Ramayana is a treasure trove of extraordinary events and mythical occurrences, which could have been visually spectacular on the big screen. Unfortunately, the film's director seems to have overlooked this aspect, resulting in a lackluster representation of the epic.For those familiar with the Ramayana, either through personal study or as part of their school curriculum, Adipurush may come as a disappointment. The film appears to have made significant changes to the original narrative, altering the essence of the story. This can be disconcerting, especially for younger audiences who are just beginning to explore and understand their cultural heritage. Instead of being a faithful adaptation, the film seems more like a 3D animation ape-man game, filled with excessive fighting scenes that overshadow the depth and philosophical underpinnings of the Ramayana.One glaring issue is the lack of strong and memorable dialogues. It appears that the director either did not have the resources to hire a competent screenplay writer or failed to prioritize the importance of well-crafted dialogue. As a result, the film feels devoid of meaningful conversations and fails to engage the audience on an emotional level. The budget seemingly prioritized cut-and-paste 3D models from other games or sources, further undermining the film's storytelling potential.While Adipurush may boast impressive visuals and a promising premise, it ultimately fails to deliver a compelling cinematic experience. Viewers yearning for a faithful adaptation of the Ramayana will be left disappointed, as the film overlooks the epic's divine miracles and profound teachings. Furthermore, the lack of strong dialogues and excessive focus on action sequences detract from the film's overall impact.In conclusion, Adipurush falls short of its potential to bring the grandeur of the Ramayana to the big screen. The film's missed opportunities, lack of faithful storytelling, and underdeveloped dialogues make it a disappointing experience for both fans of the epic and those seeking an immersive cinematic journey.

The fable of 'Helen of Troy' gets done within an Indian fantasy world in this very long film. You have a movie that is heavy with CGI and Green screen, and it's not good CGI.The acting and the story is good, some great production design here, music is brilliant and as nearly always, good songs too, just not that many here though. Plenty of action, and use of slow motion is overused, which drags the film on for three hours. A good load of editing is needed, to be sure.The motion capture is used quite a bit in this, too much really, and practical effects would of and should of been used here, so there is a lot of style with no substance, hence the problems. Action is not as great as it should of been.Entertaining as it is, it's flawed and needed polish, but I did enjoy it. Looking at the scores and reviews here, I can understand the disappointment, but I gave it a seven out of ten as it's an different take of 'Troy'. But its' not the epic that it pretends or wants to be. Can say if it's worth seeing, but it beats being bored at home. That's about as fair as I can say.

review_title: Where is it stated that these gods belonged to the Janeudhari Brahmin caste?
review_text:
This is obviously caste-based indoctrination. None of the gods being Brahmans is mentioned in any of the books. Yet these films create a narrative to whitewash Indian history with some brahminical narrative, despite the fact that not a single scripture created before 1200 AD has ever shown a god wearing thread (janeu).The writing is also based on a Ramayana that was penned 400 years ago during the bhakti movement. These filmmakers from the brahmin caste need to have done more research and presented the real Ramayana, which is a component of Indian culture. If they are unable to find it in India, similar tales are followed in other south Asian nations.But I don't believe these filmmakers, who wear thread (janeudhari caste), have anything to do with reality.

review_title: Adipurush -An Ambitious Mythological Epic That Falls Short
review_text: "Adipurush" promised to be an epic retelling of a beloved Indian mythological tale, but unfortunately, it falls short of expectations. The film, directed by Mr om raut boasts an impressive cast and a grand scale production, but it fails to deliver on its potential due to weak dialogues and a lackluster presentation of characters.One of the most disappointing aspects of "Adipurush" is its dialogues. The lines lack depth and fail to engage the audience. The script seems to rely heavily on clichés and lacks the poetic or impactful language that one would expect from a mythological epic. The dialogues are often forgettable and fail to create a strong emotional connection with the viewers. This becomes a major drawback, as a good dialogue can elevate the performances and enhance the overall cinematic experience.The way the characters are presented is another letdown. The film revolves around iconic characters from Indian mythology, such as Lord Rama and Ravana, who are meant to have rich and complex personalities. However, the character development feels shallow, and the performances fail to bring out the depth and nuances of these legendary figures. There is a lack of emotional depth and connection in the portrayal of the characters, making it difficult for the audience to truly invest in their journey.Additionally, the pacing of the film is inconsistent. While some scenes are well-executed and keep the audience engaged, there are moments where the narrative drags, and the story loses its momentum. This uneven pacing disrupts the flow of the film, leading to a disjointed viewing experience.However, the technical aspects alone cannot save the film from its weak dialogues and lackluster character presentation. Despite its grand scale and visual appeal, "Adipurush" fails to leave a lasting impact.In conclusion, "Adipurush" falls short of its potential as a mythological epic. Weak dialogues and a disappointing presentation of characters hinder the film's ability to engage and captivate the audience. While the production design and visual effects are impressive, they alone cannot salvage the film.

Adipurush, touted as an epic mythological extravaganza, falls far short of its lofty promises and leaves the audience disappointed. Director Om Raut's ambitious attempt to recreate the timeless tale of Ramayana with a modern twist ultimately proves to be a convoluted mess that fails to live up to its potential.One of the major shortcomings of Adipurush lies in its storytelling. Despite having a rich source material like the Ramayana, the film's narrative feels disjointed and lacks coherence. The screenplay fails to effectively adapt the complex characters and intricate plotlines, resulting in a confusing mishmash of sequences that fails to engage the audience. The film jumps from one event to another without providing a proper foundation or emotional connection, leaving the viewers feeling detached and uninvested in the story.Another glaring issue with Adipurush is its casting choices. While Prabhas, known for his charismatic presence, tries his best to embody the iconic character of Lord Rama, his performance lacks depth and fails to capture the essence of the legendary hero. The supporting cast, including Kriti Sanon as Sita and Saif Ali Khan as Ravana, delivers lackluster performances, further diminishing the film's overall impact. The chemistry between the characters feels forced and lacks the necessary chemistry to make the relationships believable.The visual effects, touted as one of the film's main highlights, are underwhelming at best. While there are a few visually stunning moments, the overall execution feels mediocre and fails to create a sense of awe that one would expect from a mythological epic. The action sequences, though ambitious, suffer from poor choreography and lack the finesse required to make them truly captivating.Adipurush also stumbles in its attempt to present a modern take on the Ramayana. The film incorporates elements of social commentary and attempts to address relevant issues, but the execution feels heavy-handed and lacks subtlety. The message gets lost amidst the chaotic narrative, leaving the audience perplexed and detached from the intended themes.Overall, Adipurush is a disappointing cinematic experience. Its lackluster storytelling, uninspired performances, subpar visual effects, and muddled attempt at modernization make it a forgettable addition to the ever-expanding list of mythological adaptations. While the concept held immense potential, the execution falls flat, leaving audiences longing for a more captivating and faithful retelling of the epic tale of Ramayana.

review_title: Where are the facts??? Ridiculous adaptation of a great story...
review_text: To demean our historic legacy with such amateurish story telling and 80's graphics in 2023 is an insult to the viewing audience!To the writer(s) - get your facts right!1) Ravana was not a Mughal styled ruler! He was a super intelligent leader and got caught in the wrong battle so badly that he had to be embarrassingly defeated after a long battle.2) It is hard to believe that Gods speak Mumbai Hindi like street-side goons!3) Lord Ram has fought many battles like a 14 year exile and fighting to rescue and bring back his better half from a country that was unreachable about 5000 years ago. He did all of this and led his life with great dignity. Prabhas (who was great in Bahubali) portrays him like a domestic political activist that's ready to fight at any provocation. This is just not correct...4) The saddest part in this tirade was Lord Hanuman, who was reduced to a comic rather than the mountain of strength that he is. Over a billion Indians pray to Lord Hanuman at any time when they need some strength from within. The film makers could best depict him as an ape face side-bob with a lacking physique in comparison to any of the other leads, ridiculous!For those that have missed watching this flick and are still eager, please give yourself and your senses some rest and avoid this film like the plague!

review_title: Disappointed and Disgusted: Adipurush Fails to Impress
review_text:
As an avid film enthusiast and a fan of epic mythological tales, I was eagerly awaiting the release of Adipurush with high expectations. Unfortunately, after watching the film, I can't help but feel deeply disappointed and even disgusted by the overall execution. Adipurush falls short on multiple fronts, leaving me with a bitter taste in my mouth. The dialogues are clunky and lack impact, failing to resonate. The unnecessary emphasis on violence and gore feels gratuitous and out of place, tarnishing the moral and ethical teachings at the core of Ramayana. Overall, Adipurush is a messy and disappointing film that fails to do justice to the timeless epic it is based on. It lacks coherence, strong performances, and visual finesse, making it an exhausting and forgettable experience. Save your time and seek out better retellings of the Ramayana story that capture its essence and beauty. Please DO NOT WATCH this movie.

review_title: Disappointing Adipurush: A Mess of Bad Acting, Casting, and Emotional Manipulation
review_text: I recently had the unfortunate experience of watching the highly anticipated film, Adipurush, and I must say it was an absolute letdown. The movie promised a grand retelling of a legendary tale, but what unfolded on the screen was a mishmash of bad acting, poor casting choices, and blatant MANIPULATION of sentiments. The film's bad casting choices, poor acting, and the deeply concerning DISREGARD FOR CULTURAL sentiments make it an utterly disappointing experience.However, what truly exacerbates the film's shortcomings is its blatant disregard for cultural sentiments. Adipurush takes a revered mythological tale and distorts it, causing deep offense to those who hold it dear. Instead of treating the source material with respect and sensitivity, the film takes liberties that are not only unnecessary but also disrespectful.By altering the storyline and characters, Adipurush needlessly hurts the sentiments of a significant portion of the audience. It demonstrates a lack of understanding and empathy towards the cultural significance of the narrative it attempts to depict. This insensitivity is both disappointing and deeply concerning. It becomes difficult to invest in a film when it fails to connect with the audience emotionally and remains ignorant of the cultural context it attempts to portray.In conclusion, Adipurush is a deeply unsatisfying film that disappoints on multiple levels. Its bad casting choices and lackluster performances diminish the viewing experience, while its insensitivity towards cultural sentiments further exacerbates the film's flaws. I cannot recommend this film to anyone looking for a meaningful cinematic experience, as it falls short in every regard.

ADIPURUSH - A DISAPPOINTING CINEMATIC EXPERIENCEAdipurush, touted as a highly anticipated blockbuster, fails to live up to the hype and expectations surrounding it. From its weak storytelling to questionable casting choices, the film leaves much to be desired. In this review, I will delve into the specific points that contribute to its disappointing nature.LACKLUSTER STORYTELLING:
Adipurush suffers from a lackluster and poorly executed narrative. The storytelling feels disjointed, with significant gaps and underdeveloped character arcs. The plot fails to engage the audience, leaving them disconnected from the events unfolding on the screen. The script lacks depth, relying heavily on clichés and predictable plot twists that do little to surprise or captivate viewers.MISFIT CASTING:
One of the major drawbacks of Adipurush is the misfit casting choices. The film features a star cast that seems more concerned with their stardom than delivering convincing performances. The lead actor fails to embody the character, lacking the necessary depth and emotional range required for such a pivotal role. This miscasting severely impacts the overall viewing experience and hampers the authenticity of the narrative.POOR CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT:
The characters in Adipurush are severely underdeveloped, reducing their impact and making it difficult for the audience to empathize with them. The lack of backstory and motivation for the characters leaves them feeling one-dimensional and unrelatable. The film fails to explore the emotional depth of its characters, resulting in a superficial portrayal that fails to leave a lasting impression.NCONSISTENT VISUAL EFFECTS:
While Adipurush boasts grand visuals, the execution of visual effects leaves much to be desired. The inconsistency in the quality of CGI is jarring and often takes the viewer out of the immersive experience. Some scenes are visually stunning, while others appear amateurish and poorly rendered. This inconsistency undermines the film's overall production value and fails to deliver the visual spectacle expected from a high-budget production.Pacing Issues:
Adipurush suffers from significant pacing issues, resulting in a lack of cohesion and rhythm throughout the film. The narrative jumps between scenes and timelines without proper transitions, making it difficult to follow the story's progression. The pacing often feels rushed, sacrificing crucial moments that could have added depth and emotional resonance to the film.Lack of Originality:
The film falls victim to a lack of originality, relying heavily on tried and tested tropes and formulaic storytelling. Adipurush fails to bring anything fresh or innovative to the table, leaving the audience with a sense of déjà vu. The lack of original ideas and unique storytelling elements further diminishes the overall impact and appeal of the film.Conclusion:
Adipurush, despite its pre-release hype and promising premise, disappoints on multiple fronts. Its weak storytelling, misfit casting choices, poor character development, inconsistent visual effects, pacing issues, and lack of originality all contribute to a lackluster cinematic experience. As a viewer, it is disheartening to witness the potential of a film being squandered due to these fundamental flaws. Adipurush fails to live up to its own aspirations and leaves audiences yearning for a more engaging and compelling cinematic journey.

Audiences are treated to a frustratingly subpar cinematic experience. From cringe-worthy dialogues to underdeveloped characters, this film fails to capture the essence of the beloved epic. Its third-grade VFX and a misleading storyline further contribute to its disappointing overall presentation.One of the most glaring issues with this adaptation is its dialogues. Instead of maintaining the grace and power of the original text, the script falls flat with cringe-worthy lines that do not resonate with the viewer. The lack of depth and meaningful conversations among the characters further undermines the emotional connection that audiences seek.Character strength, a crucial aspect in any adaptation, is sorely lacking in this film. The iconic figures of Ram, Sita, and Hanuman, known for their unwavering determination and inner strength, are portrayed weakly and devoid of their defining qualities. This stripping of character depth robs the narrative of its intended impact and robs the audience of the opportunity to connect with these legendary personas.The visual effects in this adaptation are a letdown, to say the least. With outdated and poorly executed CGI, the film fails to bring the mythical world of Ramayana to life. Instead of immersing the audience in the grandeur and magic of the epic, the lackluster VFX further distances viewers from the intended experience.Adding to the disappointment is the film's misleading storyline. It deviates from the original narrative, leaving audiences confused and disconnected. Instead of staying true to the moral dilemmas and intricate relationships portrayed in Ramayana, this adaptation opts for a shallow and contrived plot that fails to engage or inspire.In conclusion, this adaptation of Ramayana falls short on multiple fronts. The cringe-worthy dialogues, lack of character strength, underwhelming VFX, and misleading story all contribute to a film that fails to capture the heart and soul of the epic. It disappoints both fans of the original text and those seeking a compelling cinematic experience. Sadly, this rendition misses the mark and ultimately leaves audiences feeling unsatisfied.

A few things I disliked about the movie:

The action sequences felt like they were taken from a poor game version of the Lord of the rings or something. I don't wanna insult the Lord of the rings. Sorry, fans!6. There were many parts on the movie that didn't make sense. The scenes didn't convey the entire story or the essence of it properly.

I feel sorry for some of the cast. They looked sincere in their efforts. The story, dialogues and overall cartoonish cgi completely destroyed the essence of the movie. There are giant bats, orcs, dragons, gargoyles and what not, This should have just been a period film, instead it was turned into a cartoon/video game from 90s when everything was pixelated. Even my old Nokia phone had games with better graphics than this. I gave 2 stars just for Kriti Sanon and Prabhas for doing their best.

Adipurush, touted as a grand retelling of a beloved mythological tale, falls short of even the most basic expectations. From casting to makeup, dialogues to visual effects, every aspect of this film is marred by poor execution and a lack of creative vision. It is a clear example of how not to adapt a mythological story for the big screen.One of the glaring issues with Adipurush lies in its casting choices. The actors seem miscast, lacking the charisma and depth necessary to bring these legendary characters to life. Their performances are unconvincing and fail to evoke any emotional connection with the audience. The lackluster makeup only exacerbates the problem, leaving the characters looking artificial and out of place in their own world.The dialogues in Adipurush are cringe-worthy at best. They lack depth, creativity, and any semblance of poetic beauty that is typically associated with mythological storytelling. Instead, the dialogue feels forced and poorly written, leaving the actors struggling to deliver them with conviction. The result is an overall lack of impact in crucial scenes and a disconnection between the audience and the narrative.Perhaps the most disappointing aspect of Adipurush is its visual effects. In an era where groundbreaking CGI and VFX have become the norm, this film falls embarrassingly short. The effects appear amateurish and distractingly artificial, robbing the epic battles of any sense of awe or excitement. It feels like a step back in time rather than a leap forward in cinematic technology.The narrative itself lacks coherence and fails to explore the depth and complexity of the original mythological story it is based on. It feels like a shallow and hastily put together retelling, with key elements missing or diluted. This lack of attention to detail undermines the film's credibility and leaves the audience longing for a more faithful and engaging adaptation.In conclusion, Adipurush is an abysmal movie that fails on multiple fronts. Its poor casting, subpar makeup, cringe-worthy dialogues, and lackluster visual effects make for an unpleasant cinematic experience. It falls short of capturing the essence and grandeur of the mythological story it attempts to retell. Save yourself the disappointment and avoid this misguided and poorly executed film at all costs.

In India when a movie is made on the one of the most celebrated God Lord Shri Ram, an excitement of reliving the epic tale is very common. Indian viewers were eagerly waiting for this one.After the backlash on the initial trailer launch which postponed the release of the movie and forced creators to rework on VFX, it was expected that the released version will be much better and will do the justice.Modi government backed lyricist/dialogue writer Manoj Muntashir Shukla and BJP supported Om raut are behind this and their blessings can be seen in start the credits of the movie. But, the outcome was exact opposite of what was assumed.Makers didn't research properly. Costume designs were unimaginable and nowhere near to the characters portrayed in the Hinduism, VFX was not worth Rs 600 crore. Rajamauli can make better VFX based film in the half budget.But, the weakest link of all was the cringe worthy dialogue writing of Manoj Shukla. He portrayed Lord Hamuman like a Bajrang Dal street fighter which is insult to such a great knowledgeable person(Vidyawan, guni, ati chaatur, Ram Kaaj karibe ko aatur).Overall, the team involved in the movie collectively ruined the Epic Mythology of Hinduism and should be avoided at any cost.

Prabhas, known for his charismatic screen presence, delivers an extraordinary performance as Lord Ram. His portrayal effortlessly captures the essence of the character, showcasing both his strength as a warrior and his unwavering devotion as a prince. Prabhas's dedication to the role is evident in every scene, making him a perfect fit for the epic tale.Saif Ali Khan's portrayal of the formidable antagonist, Ravana, is an absolute treat to watch. He brings an unmatched intensity to the role, infusing Ravana with a complex mix of power, arrogance, and vulnerability. Saif's nuanced performance elevates the character, making him more than just a typical villain. The confrontations between Prabhas and Saif are electrifying and undoubtedly some of the highlights of the film.Director Om Raut's vision and storytelling prowess shine through in every frame of Adipurush. The grandeur and scale of the production are breathtaking, and the attention to detail in recreating ancient settings is commendable. The visual effects are top-notch, seamlessly blending with the narrative and adding an extra layer of realism to the mythical world. The battle sequences are awe-inspiring, leaving you at the edge of your seat, completely absorbed in the epic clash between good and evil.The supporting cast also deserves praise for their outstanding performances. Kriti Sanon as Sita brings grace and strength to the character, while Sunny Singh as Laxman displays unwavering loyalty and a fiery spirit. They add depth to the narrative, complementing the central characters perfectly.The music and background score by Ajay-Atul are mesmerizing, capturing the essence of the story and enhancing the emotional impact of key moments. The songs are beautifully choreographed, adding to the overall visual splendor of the film.

review_title: It was bound to be a failure!
review_text: Do you know what the main problem is? It is not the crappy visual effects or the terrible miscasting; it is the deprivation of heart and soul in the narrative that made things worse for Adipurush.The script is shockingly devoid of any emotional pull, which was indispensable given it is an anecdote that reverberated through centuries, a tale that is revered and known to all, such epics like "Ramayana" should have been fostered carefully with foremost sincerity and solemnness; but the creators paid no heeds to such propositions.The religious text or the slew of retellings afterwards have always preserved the core values. In contrast, this 600 Cr. Adaptation failed to summon the same emotionally charged reactions; the senses of divine affection are gone, and surrealism is nowhere to be found, mainly because of the lack of respect shown towards the source material. This was bound to fall down.

review_title: Bad direction, poor dialogues, bad animation
review_text:
I am regretting wasting my time and money on this movie. I wanted to give benefit of doubt and went to watch. Tickets were available at window (my first clue). The movie is not entertaining at all. The story is superficial and does nothing to keep you emotionally involved. The VFX is poor to say the best. Demons look like dementors from Harry Potter and that is in a bad sense. Dialogues are atrocious and use modern day slangs like "Teri Lanka laga doonga". Costumes are copied from so many fantasy movies that they further reduce your immersion. Direction is very bad and acting is poor at the best of times. Eventually I could not take it any longer and left during the interval.

review_title: Less of a movie, more of an endurance test.
review_text: When I decided to watch this film, I had made up my mind to ignore the costume and design changes, and to embrace it with an open mind. But this film, after a decent intro, turned out to be horrible. Adipurush doesn't just fail as an adaptation of the Ramayana, but also simply as a film. Even with a plethora of action sequences, it is nonchalantly executed and feels extremely dull.The VFX, first off, is horrible. I can't believe how the makers were even confident to release this in cinemas. The low quality work renders the film's action sequences unenjoyable, as a result of which they feel dragged and overlong. I'm an action movie fan but this film tested my patience with every passing second. Forget the offensive dialogue, even the simple dialogue fails to evoke any emotion, with the exception of a handful of lines.The film also turns out to be unintentionally funny many times. Lord Hanuman's character is made comedic and aggressive, and the performance by his actor is at times parody-like. For instance, when he is captured in one scene, the way he reacts before falling down is purely hilarious. I feel sad saying this because I worship Lord Hanuman and to see him like this was heartbreaking. Kriti Sanon was a surprise, though. She acted her role sincerely. Sunny Singh had this one weird, choked expression whenever he got attacked or hit. Saif Ali Khan delivered the best performance among the lot, but the weird CGI rendered many of his scenes unbearable to watch.And Prabhas? He ended up disappointing me even though I'm a big fan of him. He emotes with just one expression which is either of worry or rage, and nothing else. The film betrays the source material in many ways, especially with that 1-minute long disclaimer at the beginning explaining all the deal with the cinematic liberties and stuff and how it is not "necessarily" an adaptation of Valmiki Ramayana. Ignore that. All of that.Because before the release, its writer claimed the film to be based entirely on the Ramayana we have grown up watching and listening to. No wonder he retracted and later claimed it was not Ramayana. No doubt it isn't, because Ramayana was not a boring CGI fest with zero emotional appeal or connect. Ramayana is not just about a war between good and evil but also a study of the people involved in it. Adipurush piles up one set piece after another, filled with unwatchable VFX, but forgets to add any emotion to it. As a result, I found the film incredibly boring and hard to finish. I had to take multiple breaks, pause it and then resume it: not with the intention to enjoy but to finish it. My excitement died out in the first 45 minutes itself. Rest of the viewing was a mere chore.

review_title: The Blunder in the Bollywood movie history
review_text: Movie Review: Adipursh (Negative)"Adipursh" is an excruciatingly disappointing film that fails to deliver on its promises and falls flat on every level. From its weak storyline to its lackluster performances, this movie is a prime example of wasted potential.The plot, if one can call it that, is a convoluted mess that lacks coherence and fails to engage the audience. It attempts to blend various genres but ends up being a mishmash of poorly executed ideas. The narrative jumps aimlessly from one scene to another, leaving the viewers bewildered and disconnected from the story.The performances in "Adipursh" are equally underwhelming. Despite having a star-studded cast, the actors seem disinterested and their lack of chemistry is painfully evident. Their dialogue delivery is wooden, devoid of emotion, and fails to create any impact. It's disheartening to see talented actors wasted in such a lackluster production.The direction and editing of the film leave much to be desired. The pacing is uneven, with unnecessary scenes dragging on while crucial moments are rushed through. The action sequences, which should have been the highlight, lack intensity and are poorly choreographed. The visual effects are subpar, making the film look dated and unimpressive.

review_title: An unimaginative bland retelling of Ramayan.
review_text: Despite that lengthy disclaimer, it is indeed Ramayan. The story straight away begins with the abduction of Janaki, while quickly narrating why Raghav and Janaki are exiled for 14 years as well as Ravan getting a special wish granted that no God or devil can kill him. Rest is all about Raghav forming a Vanar sena, headed by Sugreeva and Bajrang to fight the battle against Ravan and Co, to safely bring back Janaki.The problem is simple, the vision of Om Raut to re-imagine Ramayan was completely flawed right from the beginning and unoriginally dated. The narrative simply fails to be engaging and much of the scenes painfully look cartoonish throughout. The cheesy lines in an attempt to appeal to the current generation viewers, undermine the scenes in a bad way. The 3hrs ordeal never shows any sign of providing basic entertainment and the terrific Jai Shree Ram song, keeps elevating the dud scenes and one cannot stop wondering, how a song like is wasted in such a film.There is nothing to boast about the performances. Prabhas as Raghav sticks to couple of stock expressions and his interpretation of Raghav doesn't leave a mark. Kriti Sanon as Janaki is decent but gets very little to perform. Saif Ali Khan as Ravan, is honest but the writing simply leaves him with no scope to excel. Ravan is just a regular baddie. Devdatta Nage is good as Bajrang. Sunny Singh as Sesh and Vatsal Seth as Indrajit suffer from one toned characters.I am still baffled on how this film was greenlit. The vision Om Raut had for the visual narrative spelled doom and even if CGI were to be better, it wouldn't have helped the film as those scenes were simply so dull. Hopefully it's a worthy lesson to everyone involved on how not to make a film - mythological or social.

Adipurush, directed by Om Raut, is a disappointing and misguided attempt at retelling the revered epic of Ramayana. Despite its potential, the film falls short in almost every aspect, resulting in a lackluster and unsatisfying cinematic experience. From the narrative deviations to the execution of visual effects, Adipurush fails to live up to expectations and delivers a product that can only be described as exceptionally bad.In summary, Adipurush is a deeply disappointing and exceptionally bad film that tarnishes the legacy of the epic Ramayana. From its misguided narrative deviations to its lackluster performances and subpar visual effects, the movie fails to deliver on its promise. Fans of the original story will be left disheartened, and newcomers to the tale will find little to appreciate. It's regrettable to witness such a revered narrative being mishandled and reduced to a forgettable cinematic experience.

*ADIPURUSH (2023) Film Review:*Very bad, illogical, senseless, dark, and darkest at times. They call it's based on the Ramayana; but too many mistakes and wrong conceptualizations I observed while watching Adipurush. Prabhas looks flat and graceless (with no smile/charm at all) in the role of Lord Rama, Kriti Sanon doesn't look like Mata Sita and Sunny Singh as Laxman has no weight in the film. Only Saif Ali Khan has given strong performance in the role of Lankesh; but alas he looks like more of a Mughal Emperor than Ravan. So that casting is totally unfitting and to make it further horrible we see cartoon characters as Vali, Sugriva, Angad, Jambavan, Jatayu, etc.No point of getting into the story because it is dark and after interval it becomes darkest. *Mentioning about certain mishaps then...*Lanka is not of gold here, but they have portrayed like it is made up from charcoal.Ravan's vehical is not Pushpak Vimanam, but it's animated and annoying bat.Characters look like a Superheroes of Marvel rather ornamenting mythological.Last 40 minutes just cartoon characters encounter which gives headache to the audience.Whole film is shot in closed space; not a single scene on real locations it seems.Hanuman, Indrajeet and Vibhishana speak indecent dialogues.There's a scene where Lankesh feeds meat to his bat (vehicle) which is a pathetic scene.Throughout Ravan's character looks stonger than Rama; but in the end Rama kills Ravan like a rabbit, in seconds.Romantic song between Ram-Sita.Ravan's snake bath scene.Certain terms are named based on Ramayana and some are not. For example, Laxman Rekha is called Satya Rekha in film.And blunders list goes on...Coming to the cinematic aspects then Direction is very bad, Story/Script has written without examining mythological facts, In the name of Cinematography we see dimness, Babyish VFX and CGI Work, Dialogues are very poor and badly written such that none of the dialogues give goosebumps in this so called epic and the film is longer so should have been cut by 30 minutes (specifically the prolonged last fight).Now coming to the positives then pre-interval it is tolerable. Some of the 3D effects are enjoyable by kids. Ajay-Atul's music is outstanding and 'Jai Shree Ram' song sounds enthralling indeed. Background Score is also good but becomes needlessly loud during climax. Devdatta Nage as Hanuman and Saif Ali Khan as Ravan leave their mark with powerful performances. Overall, I did not like this film though have watched it in 3D; and would rate it as 2/5 (🌟🌟). Simply Avoidable!*What I Liked Most? -* Music and Songs.*P. S. -* If you watch it in 3D then you would sleep well in the theatre because you will have black glasses on and the screen will also be dark most of the time.*BY: NIRAJ SOLANKI..!*

review_title: OTT release review - worse than what theatrical release had reviews
review_text:
600 Cr. Is too much unless Prabhas and other cast took like 500 Cr in fees and they were left with just 100 Cr for music, VFX, promotion, etc.But if they really spent 600 Cr and produced this crappy CGI and effect, either inka popat bana or there is some serious money laundering involved and it must be audited.Like, itna bekar VFX kaiiiiiise ho sakta hai 😄
Coming to movie 🎥 , I will not even go into debate how they totally "ignored" the source material "Ramayan" or Bollywood is not intellectually capable to make Ramayan for big screen.Let's assume they wanted to make their own "version" of it ...then also it had following problems:1. Not much chemistry between Prabhas and Kriti. Yes, I say Prabhas ans Kriti coz they casually acted like themselves only, unlike Raghav and Janaki.2. No consistency in motives and actions and even dialogues of characters
3. Not introducing characters, like for e.g. Angad (just one line about would have been fine though, keeping time constraint).4. That Sonu ke titu ki sweety one as Laxman ji is just wasted on screen.5. To utilise existing characters on screen 📺 in forwarding the story, they made Vibhishan ji's wife the one who tells about Sanjivani booti but why make her character unnecessarily glamorous or titillating.6. Laxman ji asking and Hanuman ji answering WhatsApp jokes was real cringe.The only saving grace are songs and music but we can watch them on YouTube 😁#Adipurush once again proves why Bollywood is intellectually incapable to adapt our nation's ancient historical texts because they try to look at these texts from Hollywood's lens and thus can never be true to the heart and soul of these texts passed down through generations to us.Only one who will let Prem and Bhakti lead the way will be able to retain the essence and adapt these texts beautifully, like how Ramanand Sagar ji did.

review_title: Immature film with limited good things
review_text: Adipurush is the most dissappointing film of 2023 by far.Prabhas looks old in the film and lacks the radiance of Rama. Sunny Singh has little scope and he doesn't really act. He didn't look like the angry young man/ devoted brother which Lakshman was.Kriti Sanon is tthe only one who looks good and acts well. She did well as Sita.Saif as Ravana did his best. But his look and character were totally ruined. In an attempt to make modern adaptation of Ramayan, the makers have created totally different ramayan; a highly dissappointing one.Ravan was a king, why would he do welding himself? And in climax he literally controls an army of bats instead of an army of demons.Indrajit captures Hanuman using a ninja star. No destruction caused by Hanuman in Ashok Vatika, no killing of Akshaykumar, sons of Prahasta, etcVibhishan's wife has an unnecesary bold scene,Indrajit's entire body has tattoo marks and Lakshman stabs him inside water; no fierce battle shown between them.Kumbhakarna suddenly wakes up by himself and goes out to fight; no struggles in waking him up or him trying to make Ravan understand at all.No mention of any other son of Ravana or the rest of demon generals in his army.Ravan's boon was even confused with that of Hiranyakashyap in the film.These are just few of the mistakes.Most of the film is dark and no efforts were made in good vfx or picturisation. Second half was very awkward and wierd to watch in theare.The songs were very nice and some even gave goosebumps.Some scenes, like meeting of Rama and Hanuman, Sita haran and Shabari's meeting with Rama were good to watch.However, I can never recommend this to someone who wants to know Ramayan or has already read the epic.You need to leave your brain at home to watch this but even then you must be ready for some unbearable moments.That's it.

Starring Prabhas, Kriti Sanon, and Saif Ali Khan, the movie had an impressive start at the box office, earning Rs 140 crore worldwide on its opening day. According to industry tracker Sacnilk, it collected Rs 65 crore on day two of release, across all languages in India. Adipurush is performing well at the Hindi box office as well, with earnings of Rs 37 crore across two days. The second-day gross in the Telugu states for Adipurush reached Rs 26 crore.

Today, I am going to review the movie "Adhipurush" with full detail. I will discuss every positive and negative aspect of this movie. So let's start with the positive side, I will share what I personally liked about this movie.Positive - The songs of this movie are really good. They bring peace to the heart when listened to, and the background music is also excellent. It successfully manages to give you goosebumps in certain scenes. Additionally, there are two or three scenes in the movie that look visually stunning. The color grading, cinematography, lighting, and other aspects are all very well done. Speaking of acting, Saif Ali Khan has given a great performance as Ravan in the movie.Negative - Ugh, the whole movie is negative, man. Matlab kya thaa yeh? There are so many mistakes in this movie, I mean, so many that if I start counting them one by one, it will take the whole day. The biggest negative point of this movie is the VFX and CGI they are really bad, beyond terrible. Every single CG character looks fake, not a single one looks real. Even Prabhas as Ram and Saif Ali Khan as Ravan, their body CGI is really bad, you can clearly see on screen how poorly the CG work was done. After CGI and VFX, if there's the biggest problem with this movie, it's the costume design and makeup. Looking at any character, you don't feel like they are from the Ramayana; in the pursuit of giving a modern touch, the filmmakers have made such a bad joke with us. And when it comes to acting, no one has done good acting except for Saif Ali Khan. Prabhas has the same facial expression throughout the entire film. And tell me, who did the casting for this movie? Prabhas as Ram doesn't fit at all. Prabhas looks more like Ravan than Ram. The same goes for Lakshman and Hanuman. In the pursuit of a modern-day adaptation, the makers have completely ruined it. And as for Om Raut, the director of this movie, forget about him. He doesn't even know the basics of direction. The National Award he received for Tanhaji, please take it back. No one could have imagined such a terrible adaptation of the Ramayana, not even in their dreams. The dialogue writer hasn't done a good job either. Some dialogues are alright, but the majority of them are really bad. The director wasted 700 crores. This movie should have never been made, it shouldn't even exist. I feel ashamed to say that this is Indian cinema. It's a stain on the name of movies.I want to give an example. Last year a movie was released called "Everything Everywhere All at Once." This movie won an Oscar in 2023, and do you know how many people worked on the VFX and CGI for this movie? Only five people. Just five individuals worked together to create the entire VFX for the movie, and it still won an Oscar. And here you guys failed miserably with a budget of 700 crore. In the eyes of the audience, this will be considered the biggest disaster movie in world history.

The much-anticipated cinematic adaptation of the beloved Indian epic Ramayana, falls miserably short of expectations. The film's execution is plagued by a series of regrettable choices, resulting in a cinematic disaster that fails to honor the source material.One of the most glaring issues with Adipurush is its abysmal dialogue. The lines are poorly written, lacking depth, and failing to capture the essence of the original epic. The film's characters, including the revered Lord Rama, are reduced to caricatures, uttering cringe-worthy lines that do a disservice to the rich and nuanced personalities we know from the Ramayana.Furthermore, the visual effects in Adipurush are downright appalling. In an age where technological advancements have brought us breathtaking spectacles, Adipurush manages to showcase some of the worst VFX work seen in recent memory. The poorly rendered creatures and underwhelming battle sequences detract from any potential excitement or engagement the film could have generated.Perhaps the most disheartening aspect of Adipurush is the filmmakers' apparent disregard for the source material's integrity. By attempting to infuse the "masala" movie formula into a revered epic like the Ramayana, they have diluted its essence and tarnished its timeless message. It is a disservice to the countless generations that have held the Ramayana dear to their hearts.Adipurush is a colossal disappointment on all fronts. Its cringe-worthy dialogue, abysmal visual effects, and disrespectful treatment of the epic source material make it a painful watch for any lover of the Ramayana. It is a plea to the filmmakers to stick to what they excel at, rather than attempting to capitalize on treasured stories that deserve a more thoughtful and respectful treatment.Above lines are from Chat GPT and it wrote a way better movie review than the movie itself. A Generative AI version of movie would be much better than this one.

Prepare yourself for an absolute cinematic catastrophe with 'Adipurush.' This film plunges into the depths of abysmal storytelling, appalling acting, and disgraceful execution, leaving audiences in a state of disbelief and utter disappointment. It is an outright insult to the art of filmmaking and a painful experience that should be avoided at all costs.Let's start with the most glaring issue: the storyline. 'Adipurush' takes a classic mythological tale and manages to completely butcher it beyond recognition. The filmmakers seem to have a fundamental misunderstanding of the source material, resulting in a convoluted mess of a plot. It's as if they threw darts at a wall covered in random story elements and decided to mash them together without any regard for coherence or logic. The narrative lacks depth, subtlety, and any semblance of character development, leaving the audience disconnected and bewildered.The acting in this film is nothing short of cringe-worthy. The lead actors stumble through their lines with an embarrassing lack of conviction, making it painfully obvious that they are out of their depth. The performances are wooden and lack any emotional range, leaving viewers wondering how such talentless actors were chosen for these pivotal roles. It's a shame to witness such a waste of potential and a failure to bring life to iconic characters.Moving on to the technical aspects, 'Adipurush' fails on multiple fronts. The visual effects are laughable, resembling low-budget video game graphics from the early 2000s. The poorly rendered CGI ruins any sense of immersion and looks more comical than awe-inspiring. The cinematography is uninspired and lacks any artistic vision, resulting in a visually bland and forgettable experience.The dialogue is another sore spot in this disaster of a film. It is riddled with cringe-inducing lines and clunky exposition, leaving no room for subtlety or nuance. The writing feels lazy and uninspired, relying on tired tropes and clichés that have been seen a thousand times before. The attempts at humor fall flat, further highlighting the film's overall lack of wit or originality.To make matters worse, the pacing of 'Adipurush' is utterly atrocious. It drags on at a glacial pace, with scenes that overstay their welcome and offer little to no narrative progression. Conversely, crucial moments are rushed through without allowing the audience to fully grasp or appreciate their significance. The inconsistent pacing only serves to amplify the film's lack of focus and direction.In conclusion, 'Adipurush' is a colossal failure in every conceivable aspect. From its butchered storyline and abysmal acting to its laughable visual effects and uninspired dialogue, it is a prime example of how not to make a film. Save yourself the agony and avoid this travesty of cinema. It is an insult to both the audience's intelligence and the rich mythology it shamelessly exploits.

The adaptation of the epic saga, Ramayan, falls short of expectations due to its inept and lackluster execution. The portrayal of characters by the actors fails to capture the essence of the original story, leaving the audience disconnected. One of the most glaring issues lies in the dialogue writing, which is not only subpar but also lacks the depth and gravitas required for such a profound narrative.The film's downfall could have been avoided if it had embraced simplicity, focusing on the core values and teachings that the Ramayan imparts. A more restrained and authentic approach to storytelling would have undoubtedly garnered greater appreciation from the audience.The utilization of animation and visual effects in the movie is a source of unintended amusement rather than awe. The laughable quality of the effects makes it difficult for viewers to immerse themselves in the narrative, as the on-screen visuals are often jarring and out of sync with the intended atmosphere.In hindsight, it's apparent that this project was driven more by commercial interests than a genuine desire to do justice to the cultural and emotional significance of the Ramayan. The film seems to have been rushed with the sole purpose of capitalizing on its potential to generate revenue, disregarding the sentiments of the billions of Indians who hold the story in high regard.In conclusion, the botched adaptation of the Ramayan serves as a reminder that faithful storytelling, meticulous character portrayal, and a sincere understanding of the source material are crucial when attempting to bring such revered narratives to the silver screen. This unfortunate endeavor missed the mark by a wide margin, leaving audiences disappointed and questioning the intentions behind its creation.

I just finished watching the movie, and I'm honestly baffled by the sheer lack of effort put into it. Makers played with our emotions. It's clear that the makers of this film were more interested in a quick cash grab than in creating a meaningful experience. The performances were lackluster at best, and I couldn't help but feel sorry for the talented actors who were dragged into this mess.The special effects were downright laughable, as if they were pulled straight from a 90s B-movie. It's as if the production team didn't even bother to do their research or invest in modern technology.What truly irks me is the disrespect shown to the audience. It's almost insulting how the filmmakers seemingly believed that they could slap together any random scenes and call it a movie. As a viewer, I deserve better than this lazy attempt at entertainment. It's disheartening to see creators take such a half-hearted approach to their craft, especially when there are countless talented individuals out there who would kill for the opportunity to bring their visions to life.In the end, this movie serves as a reminder of the importance of genuine dedication and respect for the art of filmmaking. The makers of this film should indeed feel ashamed of their work, not only for wasting their own potential but for letting down anyone who had the misfortune of watching their creation. It's a true shame that this film will be forever associated with a missed opportunity to create something truly remarkable.Huge disappointment.

I thought the bad reviews were a hype, but watched it on Netflix today and it's really horribly made. Ramayana is a household story and you must not miss out crucial details or twist facts - what makes the story fun some details like Bali and Sugriv's fight and showing that Bali was in fact an even bigger fighter than Raavan, Hanuman passing through the hurdles when crossing over to Lanka and making a chair out of his tail when not offered a seat, Angad putting his foot down etcI think where they went wrong is trying to squeeze a big story in 3 hours and ending up missing out on crucial details. They got completely lost in what to show and what to skip. Ramayana can beat all superhero movies if made properly. It must be made in 3-4 chapters and each can be 3 hour long. Nothing more needs to be said.

I would rather spend 3 hours watching a log of wood than this. Changing each scene, each dilog and the story itself and calling it historical is mockery. All the actors, writers, producers, directors and anyone and everyone connected with the film should retire immediately and start there journey as circus clowns rather than this. This movie s**ks in each department.They call it story of Ram and Sita and then they use dialogs which are pedestrian even for today. Do u think Lord Hanuman who is the living symbol of the word "Humble" would arrogantly call "tere Baapka". Mr. Mutashir or whosoever he is must surgically seal his lips and amputate his fingers.

As an avid moviegoer who appreciates diverse storytelling, it is disheartening to encounter a film that not only lacks creativity but also displays a blatant disregard for religious sentiments. Unfortunately, adipurush falls into this category, presenting a portrayal of God that is both cartoonish and disrespectful.From the outset, it becomes apparent that the filmmakers have chosen to approach the divine with a complete lack of sensitivity. Instead of recognizing the profound significance that religious beliefs hold for countless individuals, the movie reduces God to a mere caricature, stripping away the reverence and awe that should be associated with such a sacred figure.The script and dialogue do nothing to rectify this misstep. Instead of offering thoughtful insights or engaging philosophical discussions, the movie opts for shallow humor and cheap gags at the expense of religious followers. This approach not only demonstrates a lack of artistic integrity but also serves to alienate and hurt those who hold their faith dear.While artistic freedom should be celebrated, it is imperative to strike a balance between creative expression and respect for religious beliefs. Regrettably, adipurush fails to recognize this responsibility, resulting in a production that leaves a bitter taste in the mouths of its viewers. It is an unfortunate reminder of the consequences that arise when artistic liberties are taken without considering the impact on people's sentiments.In conclusion, I cannot recommend adipurush to anyone seeking a film that treats religious themes with respect and sensitivity. Its cartoonish depiction of God and the accompanying disregard for religious sentiments undermine any potential for meaningful exploration of faith. It is my hope that filmmakers will learn from this misstep and approach religious themes in the future with the consideration they deserve.

Adipurush left me utterly disappointed and frustrated with its abysmal visual effects and nonsensical storyline. This movie had the potential to be an epic trilogy, but instead, it turned out to be nothing more than a trashy attempt at cashing in on a popular mythological tale.One of the most glaring issues that plagued Adipurush was its shockingly bad visual effects. It felt like the filmmakers hired amateurs instead of seasoned professionals to handle the VFX. Even a ninth standard student could have produced better visual effects than what was presented in this film. The shoddy CGI detracted from the overall viewing experience, making it difficult to immerse oneself in the story.The screenplay was equally disappointing, lacking coherence and failing to weave a compelling narrative. Scenes felt disjointed, leaving the audience bewildered and struggling to piece together the story. The lack of depth in character development made it challenging to connect with the protagonists, further dampening any interest in the plot.The costume design was absurd and, at times, laughable. It seemed as though the designers took inspiration from a fancy dress party rather than capturing the essence of ancient mythology. This lack of authenticity only added to the overall disappointment.The casting was a major letdown as well. The actors failed to bring life to their characters, and their performances felt forced and unconvincing. It was a missed opportunity to showcase the talents of capable actors who could have elevated the movie with their performances.What frustrated me the most was the blatant misuse of Hanuman's character with abusive dialogues. This felt disrespectful and out of place in a mythological tale that is meant to inspire and teach moral values.Furthermore, it was evident that the filmmakers lacked a deep understanding of the Ramayana. Instead of delivering a fresh and engaging adaptation, Adipurush copied elements from various sources, such as Avengers, Harry Potter, and Game of Thrones, making it feel like a mishmash of unrelated themes. The portrayal of Lanka resembling Asgard on dark mode was particularly absurd and disconnected from the essence of the Ramayana.In all honesty, there is nothing that I liked about Adipurush. It was an excruciating experience to sit through this film and witness the butchering of a beloved mythology. My sentiments are hurt by this poorly executed movie, and I urge others to save their time and watch Ramanand Sagar's 90s Ramayana instead, which remains a timeless and superior retelling of this epic tale.

review_title: I am a Muslim & I dislike this movie
review_text: Just one day prior to watching this movie, I was narrating the story of Raam, Sita, Lakhsman & Rawaan. The next day when I turned on my netflx I got recommendation for this movie. Rather than how Raam got married to Sita while he shot the arrow in the fish's eye.Anyways, both the side of Raam and Rawaan were totally different. Raam's side was rather backwards vs Rawaan's side was ultra modern except for the giant bat that he rides. Rawaan's 10 faces looked like a child had done the VFX. And I can go on and on and on.My kids got a grasp of what I narrated to them one day back. But I am totally disappointed by the overall movie. It could have been made a thousand times more better that what it is.

It is with deep disappointment and a sense of outrage that I write this review for the movie "Adipurush" This film not only fails as a piece of entertainment but also shamelessly disrespects the sacred epic of Hinduism "Ramayan" .From the very beginning, it becomes apparent that the filmmakers have no regard for the rich cultural heritage and profound spiritual beliefs of Hinduism. Instead of presenting a thoughtful and respectful portrayal of Hindu practices, they resort to shallow stereotypes, distortion of facts, and a blatant disregard for accuracy.The movie shamelessly appropriates Hindu rituals and symbols without any understanding or reverence for their true meaning. These aspects, which hold immense importance to millions of people, are reduced to mere caricatures and cheap gags, ultimately serving no purpose other than to mock and belittle a deeply cherished faith.Moreover, the film's storyline is riddled with inaccuracies and misinterpretations of Hindu mythology and history. It presents a skewed and distorted version of Hindu deities and their stories, further adding insult to injury. The careless and irresponsible handling of these sacred narratives only serves to perpetuate ignorance and misconceptions about Hinduism among viewers who may not have a deeper understanding of the religion.Filmmakers have a responsibility to exercise cultural sensitivity and ensure that their work does not harm or offend any religious or cultural group. Unfortunately, "Adipurush" fails miserably in this regard. It is a clear example of how commercial interests and shock value have taken precedence over basic decency and respect for religious sentiments.I strongly advise individuals who hold Hindu beliefs dear to avoid watching this movie. By doing so, we can send a powerful message to the film industry that such careless and offensive depictions of religious practices and beliefs are unacceptable. Let us stand together against the denigration of any religion and demand responsible filmmaking that promotes understanding and respect for all faiths.

review_title: Aadipurush Movie Review - A Big Letdown
review_text: Aadipurush is a 2023 Indian movie based on a famous story called Ramayana. The film is about action and magic, but sadly, it turns out to be a big disappointment. The director, Om Raut, tried to make something great, but it didn't work out. The movie has lots of money spent on it, so it looks nice, but even that can't hide the problems. Prabhas, who is a good actor, is in the movie, but the story doesn't let him show his talent. Saif Ali Khan plays the bad guy, but his character is not interesting.The exciting fights in the movie should be fun, but they are not. They are boring and don't make you feel excited. The computer-made special effects also look fake and not real. The actors Kriti Sanon, Sunny Singh, and Devdutta Nage also don't do a good job. It's not their fault entirely; the story they have to act in is not good. The movie is in two languages, Hindi and Telugu, but this makes things worse. Sometimes, the talking and the actions don't match, and it's hard to feel connected to the story. Aadipurush tries to be a new version of the old story, but it forgets what made the story special. It cares more about looking cool than telling a good story. This is a problem because the original story is about important things like feelings and lessons.To sum up, Aadipurush is a big disappointment. Even though it looks nice and has famous actors, it doesn't tell a good story. The fights are not fun, the acting is not great, and it forgets what made the old story special. It's a lesson in how not to make a good movie.

review_title: USELESS MOVIE EVER CREATED ON THE HISTORY OF MANKIND
review_text:
Where do I even begin with Adipurush? This movie, touted as a magnum opus, turned out to be a colossal disappointment, failing to deliver on every front. From its shallow storytelling to its cringe-worthy performances, it's hard to find any redeeming qualities in this cinematic disaster.Let's start with the narrative, or lack thereof. Adipurush takes a classic mythological tale and somehow manages to strip it of all depth and substance. The screenplay is convoluted and poorly executed, leaving the audience confused and disconnected from the story. The characters are one-dimensional, devoid of any real emotions or motivations, making it impossible to invest in their journey. It feels as though the writers threw together a mishmash of scenes without any consideration for coherence or logical progression.To make matters worse, the performances in Adipurush are abysmal. Prabhas, who has proven his acting prowess in previous films, delivers a lackluster performance as Lord Ram. His portrayal lacks charisma and fails to capture the essence of the character. Saif Ali Khan, as the antagonist Ravana, hams it up to the point of absurdity, delivering cringe-worthy dialogues and over-the-top expressions. The supporting cast does nothing to salvage the film either, with forgettable performances that add no value to the viewing experience.The visual effects in Adipurush are a mixed bag. While some sequences are visually stunning and showcase the potential of modern technology, others fall flat and appear cartoonish. The inconsistency is jarring and only further detracts from any sense of immersion in the story. The action sequences, which should have been the film's saving grace, lack impact and fail to evoke any excitement or awe.Additionally, the editing of Adipurush leaves much to be desired. The pacing is uneven, with sluggish moments that drag on and abrupt cuts that disrupt the flow of the narrative. It's clear that the filmmakers were more concerned with creating grandiose visuals than crafting a cohesive and engaging film.Lastly, the music and background score, which could have been a saving grace, fail to leave any lasting impression. The songs are forgettable, and the score is generic and uninspired, doing little to elevate the film or enhance the emotional impact of the scenes.In conclusion, Adipurush is a prime example of wasted potential. It squanders a compelling mythological tale with its poor storytelling, lackluster performances, inconsistent visual effects, subpar editing, and forgettable music. It's a movie that fails to entertain, engage, or leave any lasting impact on the viewer. Save yourself the disappointment and avoid this cinematic debacle at all costs.MeanwWhere do I even begin with Adipurush? It garnered immense popularity and became a cultural phenomenon in India. Here are some of the positive aspects of Ramanand Sagar's "Ramayan":Faithful Adaptation: Ramanand Sagar's "Ramayan" stayed true to the original Valmiki Ramayana, a revered ancient Indian epic. The series presented the story of Lord Rama and his journey with authenticity and reverence, maintaining the core elements of the epic.Engaging Storytelling: The narrative of "Ramayan" was compelling and captivating, drawing viewers into the world of gods, demons, and heroes. It effectively conveyed the teachings, values, and life lessons embedded within the epic, making it accessible to a wide range of audiences.Strong Performances: The cast of "Ramayan" delivered commendable performances that brought the characters to life. Arun Govil's portrayal of Lord Rama, Deepika Chikhalia as Sita, and Dara Singh as Hanuman were particularly memorable. Their performances resonated with the audience and left a lasting impact.Production Values: Despite the limitations of the time, Ramanand Sagar's team managed to create an impressive visual experience. The sets, costumes, and makeup were well-executed, effectively immersing viewers in the ancient world of the Ramayana.Cultural Impact: "Ramayan" had a profound impact on Indian society and culture. It not only entertained but also instilled moral values, teachings, and cultural heritage in the minds of viewers. The series fostered a sense of unity, devotion, and respect for Indian mythology and traditions.Memorable Soundtrack: The soulful and melodious music of "Ramayan," composed by Ravindra Jain, added depth and emotional resonance to the series. The songs, such as the iconic "Jai Shri Ram" and "Mangal Bhavan Amangal Hari," became immensely popular and are still cherished by audiences today.Longevity and Relevance: Even after decades since its original broadcast, "Ramayan" continues to be cherished and re-aired, captivating new generations. Its enduring popularity speaks to the timeless appeal and cultural significance of the epic story it portrays.Ramanand Sagar's "Ramayan" remains a benchmark for mythological storytelling on television, offering a rich viewing experience and leaving a lasting impact on audiences.

The director had everything needed to create an epic - the best cast for the lead roles: Prabhas, Kriti, Saif Ali Khan, and the Ramayana, which provides the best plot anyone could ever have, along with a 600 crore budget. The only thing lacking was a creative team. Every scene seems to be copied or inspired from other movies. I hope Om Raut's next movie will be a great success, as he would have learned many lessons from all the mistakes he made with this movie.

review_title: Waste Of Money And Waste of Time, hurt religious sentiments
review_text:
Isse Bakwaas Movie Jindagi mai nahi dekhi.A question to the director and the other heads, how can you be so irresponsible while making this masterpiece of a story into something trash? The blatant disregard for retaining the original character personalities is appalling. Ravan, a Brahmin devotee of Shiv, known for his vegetarianism, is completely transformed in this movie, which not only disrespects the original mythology but also has the potential to hurt the religious sentiments of Hindus.Let's talk about the VFX, or rather the lack thereof. Despite having a higher budget than Brahmastra, Adipurush fails to achieve even a fraction of the visual effects quality. It's clear that more effort should have been put into fixing the VFX instead of just superficially color grading the scenes.
