review_title: A Devastating Departure from the Epic
review_text: Adipurush, a highly anticipated 3D movie adaptation of the revered Indian epic Ramayana, falls short of expectations and fails to do justice to the beloved story. The film starts with a promising rendition of the Ram Siya Ram song, accompanied by beautiful illustrations. However, the movie quickly devolves into a disgraceful portrayal of the epic narrative.The cast's performances come across as forced, with Kriti lacking the motherly aura of Sita Mata and Prabhas seemingly trapped in his Bahubali phase. Saif Ali Khan's portrayal of Ravan is criticized for resembling a character from a DJ concert rather than a formidable antagonist.Several aspects of the movie are deeply disturbing. The language used in the dialogues, such as Hanumanji's disrespectful lines, feels offensive towards a revered deity. The film takes liberties with the story, introducing inaccurate and exaggerated elements, such as Ravana's anaconda massage and the depiction of him feeding meat to the bat (which on the first place is a question marks because apparently Pushpak Viman is replaced by a creepy bat) which contradicts his Brahmin background.Furthermore, the movie includes a random erotic scene, where an unknown woman is shown along with Vibhishan, and subsequently, the woman is shown changing clothes while Vibhishan is present nearby. This scene seems unnecessary and out of place in a narrative centered on a revered epic.Overall, Adipurush fails to maintain emotional connection with the audience and strays far from the original story of Ramayana. Its poor writing, lack of authenticity, and departure from the essence of the epic are notable drawbacks. The only redeeming aspect is the music composed by Ajay Atul, which receives praise for its quality.Considering the movie's shortcomings and offensive content, it is not recommended to spend time and money on watching Adipurush in theaters. The film's attempts at modernizing the epic story result in a disrespectful portrayal that may disappoint and alienate audiences who hold Ramayana dear.

review_title: Monumental movie with heavy reliance on VFX as the main pillar
review_text: Adipurush- Monumental movie with heavy reliance on VFX as the main pillar. The essence of Ravana kidnapping Sita (portion of Ramayana) story is maintained with lots of liberty.With that sort of budget, graphics is on par with top budgeted Indian movies.Plenty of goosebumps moments- from Lord Rama meditating underwater to Hanuman ji meeting him for the first time with that warm hug, also carrying a mountain, to Vanara Sena building a bridge to Lanka with Jai Shri Ram song in the background, and finally the epic war scene that has been shot with guts and at grand scale.Kumbakarna (larger than life), Vanara Sena characters and their fights are depicted really well.Feast is to see Hanuman ji "THE REAL SUPER HERO" realizing his strengths and his counter attack. Devdatta Nage has worked hard to build that strong body and portraying Bajrang with utmost honesty.Saif Ali Khan has shown full character and given justice to Ravana's role, although his looks are really questionable (same with Indrajit).Kristin Sanon as Sita is good.Prabhas's role deserves a special mention just because of the supreme being shown as Lord Rama. His words, his deeds and actions are beyond one can imagine. This will overshadow Prabhas's acting skills as he shows little emotions during crucial scenes.Kids will love this movie.There are certain sections where movie could have been executed well.Yes, certain characterization could have been changed. Yes, certain creatures are questionable. Yes, certain dialogues could have been better. Yes, Ravana's kingdom is dark and western like (Dark theme could have been portrayed as Ravana's character).But no movie is perfect. Enjoy this imperfectness as our real superheroes battle with strong heart, with great courage and bring back respect/glory that is spoken for generations!Righteous, good deeds and the truth prevails over evil.Jai Shri Ram!

review_title: Need to show kids real ramayan before they can watch this by mistake

I'm more worried that my kids would actually watch this and get the facts wrong in scary nightmare version.I would instead show them better versions of this from the older movies where it doesn't suffer this level of mockery.Lord Ram is a character which symbolises great many things that not a single actor can truly cater in this age.I'm not a religious fanatic, but I'm educated enough to identify a mockery when I see one.So, it's a humble advice to parents who want to educate kids on the REAL Ramayan to literally avoid this at all costs, and instead get them to watch any earlier Ramayan epic movie to set the base of Ramayan right before they can get the history in this way under the banner of modern touch.Please don't fall for the VFX, they're sub-standard anyway.

"Adipurush" attempts to bring the epic tale of the Ramayana to the big screen but falls short in several aspects. Directed by Om Raut, this fantasy action film fails to deliver a compelling narrative and suffers from subpar execution and reality. "Adipurush" has garnered attention by a good PR team in fooling people with religious sentiments, but unfortunately, it fails to live up to expectations.One of the few redeeming qualities of the film is its music. The soundtrack, composed by Ajay-Atul, is the only aspect that stands out positively. The songs are catchy and well-crafted, managing to evoke some emotions amidst the lacklustre storytelling.However, the screenplay and dialogue writing in "Adipurush" by Manoj Muntashir are extremely disappointingly below par. The dialogues lack depth and fail to resonate with the audience. The B-grade quality of the writing detracts from the overall viewing experience, making it difficult to fully invest in the characters and their journey.Another major drawback of the film is the poor visual effects (VFX). The CGI work appears unimpressive and unconvincing, diminishing the impact of the action sequences and fantastical elements. The film's attempt to create a visually stunning and immersive experience falls flat, leaving the audience underwhelmed.Comparatively, "Adipurush" pales in comparison to the animated movie "Ramayana: The Legend of Prince Rama" by Yugo Sako. Released years ago, Sako's film manages to capture the essence of the Ramayana with its beautiful animation, rich storytelling, and compelling characters."Ramayana: The Legend of Prince Rama" by Yugo Sako is a testament to the power of storytelling and deserves recognition, including an Oscar.In conclusion, "Adipurush" is a disappointing film that fails to deliver on its promises. Despite a commendable musical score, the weak screenplay, wrong facts and dialogue writing, along with the poor VFX, overshadow any positive aspects.When compared to the animated masterpiece "Ramayana: The Legend of Prince Rama" by Yugo Sako, "Adipurush" falls short in terms of storytelling and execution.It is a missed opportunity to bring the epic tale to life in a captivating and engaging manner.

review_title: Wasn't there anyone who could have told?
review_text: There are certain movies that, for various reasons like the story, script, and dialogues, fall short. However, then there are stories that encompass all these elements; all one needs to do is utilize them properly to craft a good movie. Even if the movie isn't something extraordinary, these factors can still lead to substantial success.Om Raut had all the necessary ingredients, but unfortunately, he managed to create a complete mess out of it, resulting in the destruction of virtually everything you see in the movie.Movies involve the collaboration of hundreds of individuals. This raises the primary question: "Wasn't there anyone who could have informed the creators about the poor quality of the movie they were producing?"Here's why:First and foremost, there's a considerable amount of copying. The initial scene, for instance, is an exact replica of Skeletor from HE-MAN. Other instances include elements borrowed from Harry Potter, like the dementors.The movie's issues with unoriginality don't end here. From Game of Thrones, the director employs a similar presentation for Ravan as Khaleesi, and instead of a dragon, there's a gigantic bat.The trend of copying from other movies persists throughout, with nearly every scene containing easily identifiable imitations. To add to the absurdity, the director even copies the Avengers' scene from NYC. It's essentially a frame-to-frame replication, missing only the Avengers' theme in the background. Not to mention the poorly executed imitation of Ram's character, heavily inspired by Hawkeye. Even the action scenes are reminiscent of Planet of the Apes, and this blatant copying is hard to ignore.The CGI is of abysmal quality-so bad that even an animated version might have been an improvement. The fight scenes were poorly executed, inadequately presented, and simply dreadful to watch.Prabhas, known for his role in Bahubali, appears to have achieved that success primarily due to S. S. Rajamouli's direction. Unfortunately, Prabhas has been consistently disappointing since that massive blockbuster. His decision to don a mustache leaves much to be desired.Kriti Sanon, however, managed to perform her character well. She fully immersed herself in the role and justified her selection. Despite her efforts, it's unfortunate that the movie's shortcomings overshadow her performance.Saif Ali Khan, the only character that seems to have adhered to the source material, isn't exempt from the director's misguided additions of machinery, steel masks, ogres, and other unnecessary changes, which ultimately diminish his efforts.Similarly, for Sunny Singh and Vatsal (who still requires acting classes), this could have been a breakthrough opportunity. However, it seems that this time, that wasn't the case.In conclusion, this movie is an utter waste of time-lacking substance, offering nothing to captivate the viewer, and poorly crafted overall.

review_title: A differently presented version of the epic
review_text: A lot has been said and discussed about this movie in respect of the script, direction, dialogue, special effects etc. The story of Ramayan is ingrained in the minds of all Indians since childhood and they have set perceptions of the epic. This movie is the maker's interpretation and perception on how the iconic and much revered characters would look, behave and talk. The right way to review this movie however, is to assess how effectively the director has translated his screenplay onto the screen.I think director Om Raut has managed to effectively cater to audiences of all age groups. All characters are naturally shown larger than life with huge sized Saif Ali Khan as Ravan much more so. There is an unavoidable element of characters acting as if on stage rather than facing the camera. This approach has remained part and parcel of this epic whenever and wherever performed. Low key presentation would have looked unappealing. If one were to accept that he/ she is watching a differently conceived and performed " Ram Leela" then there should be no problem. Not exactly boring at any time, this movie with a long runtime has few deviations in script / concept from the earlier movies. All actors have done satisfactorily. Saif particularly has put in an impressive performance. The sets, cinematography and special effects have created the desired fantasy.

review_title: To watch or not to watch
review_text: This movie Adipurush is streaming on Netflix and even there were lots of reviews that were against this movie,I decided to watch it to know why the most of the reviews were against this movie. Everyone knows it's a disaster movie but I wanted to know it personally why people called it a disaster movie. Since I had no money to lose so decided to give it a try.The movie has lots of VFX and it's beautiful too. You can understand why it is called high budget movie. First of all,since childhood when we talk about Ramayana,we talk about Ram,Laxman,Sita,Hanuman but here it was Raghav,Shesh,Janki and Bajrang. The names were not familiar to us. Secondly Ravana had 10 heads which were one above the other,that was too not familiar to us. Again when Hanuman goes to Dronagiri in search of Sanjeevani,he brings the mountain because he thought apart from Shesh others might need it but we always read that only because Hanuman couldn't recognize Sanjeevani booti,he brings the whole mountain with him. I think creativity is good and when a person creates a good different story out of an old outline it's highly commendable. But when the outline is about any religion and religious sentiment,it should never be altered or changed. Ravana is shown taking snake massage and again that we never heard in our entire life. Had this been a very good movie if the makers would have a totally new story idea but they made a huge mistake by take Ramayana as the base of their story. The positive side of this movie is that the music is very good and of course VFX is good,but overall it's not at all a good movie.

Saw the movie on ott and my decision was right to not watch in theatre.So many flaws and misconception in it.Ravan was not Lankapati Ravan, Meghnad was not Indrajeet, Kumbhkaran almost missing.There was no Sone ki Lanka, only black mountain caves.So movie failed in conveying the rakshas sides.Hanumanji was fine, Shri Ram also fine.Except Hanumanji why whole vanar sena was apes? No charm in them.Plot running and story telling totally bad and boring.No charm in any character. I understand Shri Ram's and Hanumanji's charm was out this word. He was not Shesh, he was Lakshmanji. Totaly injustice with Lakshmanji.Ramayan is a WOW story in the whole world and they made it totally 👎

Take a bit of Avengers and Lord of The Rings, add a pinch of Game of Thrones, and top it up with Temple Run and Adipurush is served. Agreed it's no easy feat to recreate an epic tale, but with all the research and material at hand, through Tulsidas' Ramcharitmanas and Valmiki's Ramayana, if this is director Om Raut's best take on the contemporary Ramayana, we need to go back and revisit the original in all its glory, and restore our sanity. Adipurush is merely a Bollywood-ised version of one of the most epic tales that ever existed. Considering the significance of Ramayana's place in Indian mythology and literature, the directors should have put more of their heart and soul into creating it. Despite the great performance by the actors playing Ram and Hanuman, the movie still is able to show much gloss and not much substance.

review_title: Adipurush is the best adaption of Ramayana by far
review_text: Adipurush is predominantly an Indian Hindu mythological devotional movie. Taking it as a superhero movie will not work. It's basically about the triumph of good over evil. Seeing it on the big screen, I felt transported to Threthayuga when Rama fought Ravana fought his righteousness. The movie is a retelling of Ramayana from Vanavasa (serving a 14-year exile in the wilderness) to Yuddakanda (ultimate war between Rama and Ravana in Lanka) with computer generated graphics mostly the backdrops and additional characters like vanaras and demons. Because it's a beloved mythological story, we do not need explanations and details which are obviously omitted to fit in the length of the file which is near 3 hours.The songs by Ajay-Atul are very soulful and fit the mood of the movie and transcending. The characters portrayed by Prabhas as Raghava, Kriti as Janaki, Saif as Ravana and Devdatta as Bhajrang are very befitting. In fact, they make the beloved story much more comprehensible through their expressions. The narration is very simple and yet contains the major incidents and details which are crucial for the viewer to feel the proceedings rather than just watching them but at the same time omit the minor details which are present in the scriptures. Direction mostly focuses on the emotional aspects of the film and tries to enhance the viewing experience rather than making the viewer indulging in the chronological occurrences of that period of time, which are obviously present in the books and TV series.It has been a controversy causing movie since it offended the sentiments of masses due to the deviation of narration and some dialogue from the source material but what I felt is that it's just an another adaption of Ramayana. We cannot compare it with Ramanand Sagar's 80's TV series Ramayana as it was also an adaption of Tulisidas's Ramcharitmanas. So, there is no truth in any adaption or interpretation of the story as the original story by Valmiki itself was his own interpretation of what happened during the Thretayuga.Prabhas excels as Raghava and Saif excels as Ravana and Kriti is believable as Janaki. Though there is more focus on Ravana for establishing the fact that the greater the evil the greater the victory of good over it. Music is very soulful especially the title track Ram Siya Ram and background score is apt. Production values are good, though computer generated, considering the fact that it's the most expensive Indian film by far.Despite some flaws, I just suspended my disbelief during some scenes where there was an exaggeration of dialogue or lack of some precise CGI or over-use of CGI and color tone and it worked for me and could enjoy the movie for what it is. At least, it's much better than the junk shown in marvel movies which are completely factitious comic-based. Ramayana is not factitious as it's proven happened for real by the archeological evidences in Ayodhya time and time again. So, the real legacy of Raghuvamsa is translated on screen with CIG enhancements for the audiences' watching pleasure and taking it that way is the only option or if one is to point out the mistakes in it would simply mean that one cannot enjoy anything that's presented for grasping.The Ramayana story, no matter how it is told, is timeless and timely - timeless because the story is first of its kind, true and eternal and timely because the values still hold good in modern times. It's not just about the war between Rama and Ravana but the fighting ones inner demons which are much worse than 10-headed Ravanasara and can be applied to ones own complete inner conflicts rather than to external entities, as a takeaway.Overall, from what I have experienced, Adipurush is the best adaption of Ramayana by far - 11 out of 10 stars!

Adipurush (2023) Streaming on NetflixAdipurush is a 2023 Indian mythological action film based on the Hindu epic Ramayana. The film stars Prabhas as Raghava, the prince of the Ikshvaku dynasty, who sets out to rescue his wife, Janaki (Kriti Sanon), from the demon king Lankesh (Saif Ali Khan).My main problem with Adipurush is that it feels like a pale imitation of Western films like Game of Thrones. The characters are one-dimensional and the plot is predictable. The action sequences are well-choreographed, but they are too long and drawn-out.I understand that the makers of Adipurush were trying to do something different with the Ramayana story, but I think they missed the mark. The film is too long, too violent, and too dark. It is not a film that I would recommend to anyone.I also found the film to be quite dark and violent. The Ramayana is a story that has been told and retold for centuries, and it is usually a story of good versus evil. However, Adipurush takes a more cynical approach, and it often feels like the film is reveling in the violence.The characters are one-dimensional. Raghava is a generic hero, Janaki is a damsel in distress, and Lankesh is a mustache-twirling villain. The plot is predictable. You can guess what is going to happen from the very beginning. The action sequences are too long and drawn-out. They take up a lot of the film's running time, and they become boring after a while. The film is too dark and violent. There is a lot of blood and gore, and it is not suitable for younger viewers.Overall, I was disappointed with Adipurush. It is a film that tries to be too many things at once, and it ultimately fails to do any of them well. I would give it 1 star out of 5.

review_title: Not even a Ramayan for kids.

Even to some extent the looks of the character look pathetic, especially Raghav or Shri Ram. Prabhas's makeup is bad to be honest. Arun Govil looked so much better in Ram's role. The final battle had to be epic but it turns out as bad as Raghav's look.Watch it if you want to see to what extent an Epic can be butchered.

review_title: Fortunately, I managed to avoid watching this dreadful movie in the theaters.
review_text: In a disheartening turn, this pivotal tale has been mishandled with a surprising lack of care. The film's narrative appears to lack careful consideration, raising doubts about its release. The potential ramifications of such a portrayal on young audiences could be problematic for future understanding of the Ramayana. A more diligent approach involving thorough research, immersion in traditional presentations, and studying the exemplary "Ramayana" series could have ensured a graceful and simplified depiction.Should one perceive the antagonist as Raavan, a potential source of misunderstanding about the Ramayana emerges. While the film's visual effects are subpar, the crux of the issue lies not in these effects but in the portrayal of characters and their actions. Take, for instance, Raavan's peculiar appearance, blending elements of Islamic leaders and peculiar attire. His inexplicable bat-riding lacks justification, while his entourage appears more caricature-like than substantial.Indrajit's portrayal, akin to the Flash with Conor McGregor's attire, seems out of place for the Ramayana's context. A feeling of connection is elusive in the film's introduction of Lord Rama, his battle against anonymous computer-generated creatures lacking clarity. Even though the Ramayana boasts a rich narrative, Raavan's motivations in the film appear juvenile and muddled. A scene involving Laxman's arrow and Raavan's sister comes across as juvenile and unfinished, and the attempt to condense Lord Rama's exile into a fleeting three-minute scene leaves little room for character immersion.The sole moment of connection arrives through a brief animated scene with Jatayu, though this attachment remains stronger with the bird than with Mata Sita or Lord Rama. The reliance on computer-generated imagery is evident even in the portrayal of Saif Ali Khan, with his head seemingly hovering atop a fabricated body, sporting ten heads. Lord Rama's character feels mechanical, lacking the depth expected of a multi-dimensional portrayal of a divine figure.The culmination sees Lord Rama's triumph over Raavan, yet uncertainties linger about the strategic arrow that fells the antagonist. Raavan's passivity following this event remains puzzling. The film's conclusion indulges in an extensive thirty-minute display of computer-generated visuals, eclipsing the narrative's core and obstructing character connection.The dialogues falter, oscillating between formal Hindi and slang, disrupting the film's flow. Lord Hanuman's dialogue choices lack reverence, while another character's choice of words lacks decorum and respect. The film's dialogue fails to honor the nuances of these esteemed characters.In summation, this film stands as a profound letdown. Followers of Lord Rama and audiences in general would be prudent to abstain from investing their time and resources in this endeavor. Evading this cinematic venture is a sound decision, given its misrepresentation of a cherished tale and its characters.

review_title: Adipurush = Bahubali Parody + Duke 3D + Planet of the Apes + Avengers + some rubbish
review_text: Why does someone have to spend 600 cr to make such a disaster?? And how in God's name did it make 350cr at the box office?Adipurush has no role in this movie except for that motivational speech before the fight. From the time the dude went underwater in the first scene to when he tried to kill Ravana, all his duties were being outsourced. Next Janaki.. Holy smokes, she's got no role in the movie apart from sitting under the cherry blossom tree! Hanuman aka Bajrang is the main character of the film. He's there everywhere. Rama's brother Bharata brought the soldiers of Ayodhya to help Rama. Where is he in this movie??And Ravana = Thanos + Thor!!I am surprised there was no item song in the movie. They should have brought in Shurpanaka to do an item song, that would have been the cherry on the cake!!My God, I find it difficult to believe that the cast and crew spends ridiculous amounts of money to go study theater and then make a fool of those institutions!!

I watched the movie on Netflix.The movie starts with a min long disclaimer reading about creative liberties and how they want the audience to keep an open mind.Thats goes to show, the writers and directors know they effed up due to the reaction of the audience.But I kept an open mind, enjoying every aspect of the movie, but yes, at times it was difficult.They writers could have explored the journey of their vanwaas than just concentrating on the last year or so with their encounter of Ravan. They could have also explored the divine weapons, but Bhramastra was occurred only once.The infamous Pushpak Viman was shown 3-4times on screen, but Ravan decides to use a Bat.In choice of actors, Kriti Sanaon and Saif Ali Khan did an excellent job, given the characters.Prabhas I believe was a wrong choice to depict Ram. Prabhas brought the same character of Bahubhali to this movie. When Ram is supposed to show divinity and wisdom, which translated into a warrior. He displayed arrogance at times, and was more concerned with dialogue delivery.The visual effects were way bad, with this day and age, such beginner stuff is not expected. Right from the first scene, the effects were bad.Even the monkey army which was designed was just copy and paste.The characters that they inserted. The Rakshas looked like ogres, some initial ones looked like Dementors. But atleast they sent a good message, when they showed one rakshas flossing his teeth!!!Overall the movie should have been a series or atleast in 2-3 parts, where they could have explored the Ramayan, and a huge missed opportunity. The script writer should have interviewed experts, and the dialogue writer should have stuck to nice dialogues depicting knowledge and divinity than chapripan.

The movie has deeply hurt my religious sentiments! Strict action should be taken against everyone who was involved in making this joke, So nobody dares to mock Hinduism ever again! "Does anyone imagine the religious characters to be in existence in the way they are shown in the movie? The attire worn by the characters in the movie, do we imagine our gods to be like this? Ramcharitmanas is a sacred text, people recite it before leaving their homes and you depict it in such a pathetic way. Few people could not watch the film completely. Those who respect Lord Rama, Lord Laxman and Maa Sita, they can not watch such a movie.

review_title: Watch if you wanna experience regret.
review_text: "Matrix Revolutions": Get ready for an eyeful of CGI gone haywire! The film throws in a gazillion computer-generated tricks that might leave you more puzzled than a Rubik's cube. They practically handed the VFX team a blank check and let them loose in a candy store. What's the result? A visual whirlwind that's more chaotic than a thunderstorm in a teacup.Now, let's talk dialogue - or lack thereof. Forget about meaningful conversations; it's all about actors bouncing around like kangaroos on caffeine. You'd think you stumbled into a trampoline park rather than a movie theater. Picture this: 90 minutes of 90% SFX. It's like watching a fireworks show on steroids, minus the 'oohs' and 'aahs.'If Marvel ever had a really bad day and produced something during nature's call, this movie might be the result. It's a full-on CGI overdose, drowning out every bit of substance. This flick isn't just bad; it's like biting into a whole lemon when you expected lemonade. Trust me, this one's a contender for the hall of shame.

review_title: Injustice to the story, to actors and to the audience
review_text:
Story: Ramayan is an epic, which every Indian knows by heart. The story involves the biggest God of the third most populous religion in the world. Rewriting such a thing is one of the biggest mistakes.E.g. Shabri placement was wrong,
vaidya sushen was replaced by a seductive lady,
Rawan shown as lord of Bats,
pushpak viman replaced by a dragon,
langur resembling army of Sugreev replaced by many different breeds of monkeys,
Meghnad becomes Flash from Hollywood. The whole movie is full of goof ups.Dialogues: not up to mark. A much more decent language was expected.Development of Characters: each character in Ramayan is very beautifully developed. But Adipurush was not able to develop even a single character. Hanuman ji, Ravan, Sugreev, meghnad and all others needed some better representation. The movie disappointed me here. The movie wasted more than half an hour panning and zooming on Ram and Rawan from different angles. It became so boring that we felt like having a remote to forward the scenes. Unfortunately we were in theatre.Music: Background score was cacophonic. With the story so long you don't have a place for a song sequence but they decided to insert some extremely forgettable songs.Computer Graphics: It felt like the whole movie was shot on a green screen. The movie was full of animations and animations were poorer than the first Harry Potter. Low FPS was really disappointing.Direction: It can simply compete in the most poorly directed movies/play/tv show ever made, based on Ramayan.Picturisation: they have used lots of CG and animation which, as I mentioned is of poor quality. Most of the movie is dark. Lanka is black coloured.Actors: kriti Sannon looks Beautiful, and did justice to her role, Prabhas looks and feels almost like bahubali. Sunny Singh looks unconvincing as a short tempered Laxman. Hanuman's make up was really bad. But the biggest wastage was of one of the finest Actors Saif Ali Khan. The way he was waving his shoulders was strange. All of them are great actors, but it seems like the director got confused in the technology and art of movie making.Opinion: I normally read IMDB reviews before going to a cinema. But today I specifically downloaded its app to write this review on this movie.

To begin with, "Adipurish" is a captivating movie that deserves at least one viewing. It offers a fresh perspective on the epic tale of Ramayana by presenting Ravana not only as a king but also as an engineer and blacksmith.This movie explores the possibilities of Ramayana, particularly within the Indian context. It acknowledges that the oldest and most authentic version of the Ram Katha originates from the Buddhist Jatak Stories, specifically the Dasharath Jatak Katha.Alongside the Buddhist version, there are also Jain Ramayana and Brahminical Ramayanas, with Valmiki Ramayana being the oldest among the latter.It's important to note that there exist hundreds of variants of the Ramayana, and "Adipurush" adds a unique narrative to this extensive list. The story is an intriguing interpretation primarily based on Valmiki's Ramayana, diverging from the more popular Ramacharit manas, a 500-year-old rendition in the Awadhi language by the author Rambola Dubey, also known as Tulsidas.Overall, "Adipurush" offers an interesting and distinct exploration of the Ramayana story, making it a worthwhile experience to delve into.

On the unusual decent rating of three stars out of five, i.e., six out of ten:The film has been thrashed since the launch of the teaser, and I had given up completely on the movie. Countless negative reviews, memes, trolled trailers, and commentary on the poor dialogue and VFX---the stream of critique on the movie was endless. I just went in anticipating the worst thing. And when the movie was over, I felt it was not "that" bad. Gets an extra star just because I was sensitized to bad bits, and the good bits felt decent, so it ended up been an anticlimactic experience for me. Had I gone in blind, I would have rated it either one or two... the anticipation of absolute worst helped. Also the acceptance of the movie being a "loosely-adapted" film based on Ramayana---just another action flick---helped me to just relax and watch it without the burden of negative publicity. Don't do the folly of equating it to the Ramayana despite what the title, the moviemakers, or other people affiliated with the movie say---life will be much easier that way; otherwise, all you will see is endless flaws, and then even negative stars would be insufficient to rate the movie.Coming to the movie:Major things that did not work for me:a) Prabhas: One-tone angry man look. It has been six years since Baahubali 2 released, and he is still caught in that Baahubali mold. Awful. All his T-series flicks, including Saaho and Radhe Shyam, have been horrendous. Perhaps it was the genius of Rajamouli and freshness of Prabhas to non-Telugu audiences that shined in the Baahubali duology.B) Color grade of the film: Even in a 4k premiere theater with a 3D show, the entire film looks so dark. Many things are not visible at all, which might have been done to hide the many valid criticisms when the teaser was launched. No day shots or lack of light felt so off throughout the film.C) Animation: There are several interesting, nice bits of VFX and animation in the film mixed with equally poor, low-quality, horrendous effects. The most notable of the poor animation shots being everything to do with the Vanar army (Lord Ram's army) and Lanka army (Ravana's army). The sequence of Bali and Sugriva fight was simply yuck. Several of the animation shots were simply unrefined and done without due attention to the detail. The intro scene of Lord Ram also felt shoddy (I was like what the heck are Dementors doing in the film 😂).Major thing that worked for me:a) Sound: The sound department did good (not talking about the music here). Perhaps it was the Atmos effect, or the choice of my seating to be in the dead center of the theatre, that the sound effects and design felt good throughout the movie.B) Watching on a big screen in 3D. The scenes getting trolled everywhere did not look "that" bad in a big, good-quality theatre. Also some visual effects looked nice.C) Once you accept that the film is "very" loosely based on the original text, I liked the dark, evil (and comical in parts) portrayal of Ravana and Lanka. Although I am sure that I am in a rare company here.On Om Raut: I liked his Lokmanya Ek Yugpurush, and thought that Tanaji was okayish--sub-par at best unlike how much people enjoyed it. The difference in quality of the two films is fairly evident when you switch from a real movie like Lokmanya into the use of VFX and animation heavy film like Tanhaji. Tanhaji felt unreal, visually dark, and unrefined in the CGI domain. Alas it at least had some live action unlike Adipurush where they bit more than they could chew---everything looks so cartoonish. Very little feels live action, which is a major bane of the film.On Manoj Muntashir Shukla: I did not give much attention to the dialogues, so no comments---although I can firmly say that at least the dialogues were not as awful as in Brahmastra 😂.

There is no need for so much hate towards this masterpiece. It was very well made. Was it perfect, ofcourse not, no movie is, but the time and effort that was put into the film must be appreciated. Yes the VFX could have been improved, but the design and execution was excellent. Watch it to enjoy it and not tear it down, as you're missing the point. Watch it and embrace the story. There has never been such a telling of the Ramayan done to meticulously with a good use of technology. Hats off to Om. Some elements from the Ramayan are absent, but this is meant to be a movie.Do yourself a favour and enjoy it for what it is meant to be. I hope this does not discourage the filmmakers, and they make m ore films like these. I found the visual aesthetic pleasing, you do want to see some flawed VFX.There is so much thought that went into the production value and design. So appreciate all of this.

review_title: Adipurush: A Terrible Film That Disrespects the Ramayana
review_text: I was very disappointed with Adipurush. The VFX was terrible, the acting was subpar, and the dialogue was cringeworthy. The film felt like a low-budget, amateur production.The acting was also very poor. Prabhas was miscast as Rama. He didn't have the charisma or the gravitas to pull off the role. Saif Ali Khan was the only actor who gave a decent performance.The dialogue was also very bad. It was full of cheesy one-liners and forced humor. It felt like the writers were trying too hard to make the film cool and edgy.The film also disrespected the Ramayana. It took the epic story and turned it into a shallow, action-packed spectacle. The film's makers seemed to have no understanding of the religious and cultural significance of the Ramayana.

If graphics would be better it will get good ratings. Graphics not apt for big budget. Overall nice experience.

review_title: An Epic Indian Mythology Film that Captivates
review_text: "Adipurush" is a significant achievement in Indian cinema. I was impressed by the stunning visuals, thrilling action, and Prabhas's outstanding performance as Rama. It's a film that seamlessly blends history and mythology with modern technology, creating an unforgettable experience.However, as someone not well-versed in Indian mythology, I occasionally found it a bit challenging to grasp the story's context. Some supporting characters like Sita and Hanuman seemed to lack the attention they deserved.Overall, "Adipurush" is a film worth watching, especially if you enjoy epic storytelling and high-quality production. It's a visual masterpiece that pleases the eye and offers heart-pounding action. While not without its flaws, the film successfully elevates Indian mythology onto the big screen in a grand and captivating manner. I highly recommend watching it, especially if you want to experience the charm and beauty of Indian mythology in a modern epic.

review_title: The Worst Representation of the Mythology
review_text: This is the worst representation of the mythology. Bollywood isn't mature enough to craft the great Ramayan. Excessive VFX has overshadowed the core story that's close to everyone's heart.Om Raut, you have forgotten the fundamental essence: the story. Don't introduce unnecessary modern elements and attempt to emulate Hollywood or South Indian films, especially when adapting Ramayan.@prabhas, you are no longer the star/hero we admired, as you failed to represent our true hero. Move past your "Baahubali" persona; you're portraying a much grander character in Prabhu Shreeram. It's time to shed your stardom and embrace the depth of your role.Overall, this was a completely failed attempt at adapting the Ramayana. The Ramayana of the 90s by Ramananda Sagar remains an epic that will forever be cherished in our hearts. This recent adaptation doesn't even come close.Filmmakers, don't play with the emotions of the masses.I would give it 0 stars.Jai Shreeram!

review_title: Injustice to character of Lord Hanuman
review_text: Lord Hanuman was well educated and had the knowledge of all the Vedas, he was also a pious scholar. He never used rowdy type words like "kapda tere baap ka, etc." He used to wear saffron and yellow loincloth, bracelets on his wrists and ankles, adorned with rudraksh mala alongwith the sacred thread "janeu" instead of cheap leather outfit as shown in the movie.What's most irritating is the fact that he's depicted as a timid and childish character who was reluctant to go to Lanka alone at first, gets easily intimidated by Indrajeet and almost defeated by Kumbhakaran in final battle is completely wrong, hence unacceptable.

review_title: Catastrophe of a Revered Epic Ramayana
review_text:
Manoj Munatshir had gone nuts with the notorious dialogue writing by making mockery of the Epic and stating that they're inspired by Ramayana. Also, his marketing strategy included to use "Ramayana" as a movie name which is just an inspiration for dialogs then why its tale and characters are exactly replica of holy Ramayana. Bollywood is a joke and these filmmakers are not only just ridiculous they're stupid and brainless. None of the cast is a remote fit to the character.Even before we talk about cast the writers have not done any homework. It's not a movie it's a disaster.Biggest Mistakes:
(1) Ravan eating meat. He was a Brahmin, he abducted Sita only to prove his power.(2) Jatayu did not die right after Ravan injured him.(3) Joke of 10 faces of Ravan.(4) Obscenity in projecting Sita's character in the way of dressing.Just a very wrong movie.

I cannot believe they actually made something like this. It's almost like they are mocking the epic "Ramayan" and this attempt at mockery is so pathetic that it does even evoke any anger in you. Instead you die laughing at the level of patheticness, if that is even a word. Just about everything is so so so pathetic. The casting director should change careers. On second thought, everyone associated with this epic disaster should think of alternate careers. Yes, it is that bad!The acting , the characterization, the direction, the cinematography and don't even get me started on the CGI and VFX- everything is horrendous. At some points it is confusing whether it is a film or a video game.They could have created something so great given how interesting the Ramayan is and all the characters in it are. But instead they created this.

The government can criticize this movie, and the Indian people can become revolted, offended, and whatever else afterward. However, for me, I found this movie completely suitable for all purposes. The primary objective of this movie was to acquaint the upcoming generation with Indian culture and their roots, and I believe the movie succeeded entirely in achieving that goal. This was the underlying theme of the film, and it was executed very effectively, without aiming to offend anyone.The closed-minded perspective of those who criticized this movie (scoring it 3.2 on the scale here) highlights and epitomizes narrow thinking. Of course, I watched the OTT version of the movie, so I didn't find any issue with the dialogues at all. This is because the movie was made in 2023 (released), not like 40 years ago, and we need to move forward with the times while also trying to pass on the culture to the next generation. I believe the creators of this movie were quite successful in doing so.If someone is complaining about the visual effects, then what exactly are Indian audiences expecting? Were they anticipating Avengers-like VFX or Spider-Man or DC-level budgets to enhance the visual effects? Let's be realistic. Most of us Indians grew up with characters like 'Fauladi Singh', 'Shaktimaan', and for the love of these things, let me also mention Indian sci-fi 'blockbusters' like 'Shiva Ka Insaaf', 'Mr. India', and so on. And if we compare that (which is mostly what Indian audiences have been served and embraced) with the effects in this movie, they are quite sophisticated... they are considerably good. So, we can't compare apples and pears. Let's not compare it with a Marvel or DC budget film, but instead, recognize that the producers have gone the extra mile to present us with decent VFX.I'm a sci-fi buff, and I'll say it again, the VFX are pretty okay. Therefore, I don't comprehend why people have criticized this movie. I myself went through the Indian education system, and Ramayan and Mahabharat were part of our curriculum, and I grew up with them as a Hindu. This movie conveys the right message, which I was able to communicate to my kids through their eyes, in the year 2023, where we have access to jet-age technology and AI at our fingertips. So, I must say congratulations to the creators of this movie. Of course, there are some mistakes that I could point out. For example, Ram not hiding behind a tree or obstacle to kill 'Vali', even though that was the case, and not showing when 'Raavan' meets his end, then he praises and honors RAM for showing him the path to salvation, etc. So, some minor details were missing, but to bring an idea as extensive as the Ramayan (which has around seven 'kands') onto the screen in about two and a half hours is an enormous task. In fact, it's so immense that people might not realize the extent of effort required to create something like this and condense it within two and a half or three hours.I think the Indian audience (the majority of viewers of this film have Indian roots) might be better off watching films like 'Pathan' and others of that sort. It's a tragedy that there might never again be quality epic movies made, just because this one was criticized so vehemently & debunked.

In order to make a movie, first of all, you have to turn things over and over in your head, even if it takes long time to do so. Ideas must be clear and understandable. Otherwise, it became an absolute storm of meaningless ideas, which combined together is the perfect example of how to NOT make a movie. Unfortunately, this is exactly what happened with this 179-minutes unbearable attempt-of-a-movie. In the very first place, STOP making movies only for the sake of the fame of an actor, no matter who the actor is. It felt just like it was Prabhas' show throughout the movie, like Raghava got replaced by Prabhas in the mythology. Then, all the actors involved in this 75-million-dollars crash test movie should take acting lessons because even a child can act better than these people performing only for remuneration and fame, even including Prabhas, to my greatest dismay because I liked his acting in Baahubali and Saaho. Speaking of children, I think that the whole VFX were made with drawings made by kindergarten children, like with the depiction of skeletons looking like a personification of Death but are completely cartoonesque instead of being a little bit more "real". Even 2015 fantasy children-aimed movie Puli made it better. So I would say that if walking backwards was an Olympics sport, then Adipurush would be a gold medalist. The songs and the music bled my ears, as well as the the images bled my eyes. Watching this movie, we know that the 75 million dollars went directly in Prabhas' and Kriti Shannon's wallet. They were paid for this freak show so they're happy now without even giving a single damn about the quality of this vulgar-language parody of mythological events. Dialogs are completely unbelievable... this is exactly how I imagine discussions between people in that kind of experiment where newborn were put in a house to grow inside and create a new language on their own. Biggest waste ever.

If you had hoped for Bollywood reproducing some Avengers + Planet of the Apes + Lord of the Rings type scenes, this is an attempt (bad rip off like, but an attempt nevertheless). If you had hoped for Bahubali by Bollywood, maybe an attempt too (average, at best). But, if you had hoped for a solid attempt at recreation of Ramayana with some great visual effects, this isn't it. Actually it is just simply bad when it comes to dialogues (uncouth, distasteful, crass at times), storyline (God knows which Ramayana this is), or the cast (except, maybe, Saif Ali Khan). It could have been so much. So so much actually. But but but - it is poorly done.Ramayana's is a storyline so elegant, it is probably very hard to spoil it. Forget the religious aspect for once even - the literature and the storyline itself is superb, and it flows. Amazingly, these fellas managed to royally break that script apart too. I mean, how?Dialogues in some instances are going to make you almost puke. No seriously, they will.Also - Ravana is a Bat- (controlling) -man, riding a bat instead of Pushpak, which is there in the movie, just not used by Ravana. Apparently, Ravana prefers bat-rides. Speaking of. Indrajeet / Meghnad is Flash morphed with Doctor Strange. I mean they could have stuck to either of Marvel or DC, at least!!I can go on. I won't.2 stars cos I love superhero movies.

review_title: Adipurush: A Disappointing Adaptation of a Revered Epic
review_text: Adipurush, directed by Om Raut, falls short of expectations as it attempts to condense the vast episodes of the mythological epic into a three-hour movie. The overly tight plot sacrifices crucial storytelling elements, resulting in a fragmented and confusing narrative that fails to do justice to the original story.The storyline of Adipurush had to solely revolve around the abduction of Maa Sita by Ravana and Lord Rama's subsequent efforts to rescue her with the help of Hanuman and his followers. Unfortunately, the movie neglects to establish a cohesive track of events, leaving audiences feeling disconnected and bewildered. The lack of attention to the "how" and "what" aspects of the story further compounds the issue, leaving viewers craving a deeper exploration of the characters and their motivations.Despite boasting a talented cast, Adipurush disappointingly underutilizes and misrepresents its ensemble. The potential of the actors remains largely untapped, resulting in shallow and unconvincing character portrayals. It is disheartening to witness such a group of performers not being given the opportunity to shine.The dialogues in Adipurush drastically fail to evoke the emotional depth and resonance expected from a mythological epic. The writing feels loose and uninspired, lacking the power to truly engage the audience. The dialogues are a missed opportunity to connect with the viewers on a deeper level and leave them emotionally invested in the story.The usage of technology in Adipurush is a significant letdown. Rather than enhancing the movie, it appears to detract from the overall experience. The execution of the visual effects and other technological elements feels forced and out of place, detracting from the authenticity and charm of the story.In conclusion, Adipurush is a disappointing adaptation of a revered epic. The overly tight plot, lack of a coherent storyline, underutilized cast, weak dialogues, and mishandled technology all contribute to a subpar cinematic experience. With a rating of one star out of ten, it is difficult to recommend this movie to anyone seeking a faithful and immersive retelling of the Ramayana.

review_title: Out standing movie so I walked out of theater
review_text: Detailed Review: A question to the director and the other heads, how can you be so irresponsible while making this masterpiece of a story into something trash? The blatant disregard for retaining the original character personalities is appalling. Ravan, a Brahmin devotee of Shiv, known for his vegetarianism, is completely transformed in this movie, which not only disrespects the original mythology but also has the potential to hurt the religious sentiments of Hindus.Let's talk about the VFX, or rather the lack thereof. Despite having a higher budget than Brahmastra, Adipurush fails to achieve even a fraction of the visual effects quality. It's clear that more effort should have been put into fixing the VFX instead of just superficially color grading the scenes.The dialogues in Adipurush reach new depths of mediocrity. While attempting to portray a more modern interpretation, the filmmakers fail to put in the necessary effort to create dialogues that can be understood and appreciated by any generation. The result is a disjointed and poorly crafted script that leaves viewers cringing and yearning for substance.In conclusion, my disappointment with Adipurush is immeasurable, and it truly ruined my day. The film's disregard for character authenticity, subpar VFX, and atrocious dialogues render it an abysmal cinematic experience. It fails to deliver on its promise of an engaging and respectful adaptation of the revered Ramayan Epic. It serves as a disservice to both the source material and the audience, leaving a bitter taste in the mouths of those who had hoped for so much more.

The film revolves around the legendary tale of Lord Rama and his epic battle against the formidable demon king Ravana. Director Om Raut weaves together a compelling narrative that stays true to the essence of the original myth while adding his own creative flair. The screenplay strikes a perfect balance between staying faithful to the source material and offering fresh interpretations, making the story accessible to both fans of Hindu mythology and newcomers alike.One of the film's biggest strengths lies in its exceptional visual effects and production design. The grandeur of the sets, intricate costumes, and awe-inspiring landscapes transport viewers into a world that feels both mythical and tangible. The action sequences are masterfully choreographed, showcasing epic battles and breathtaking stunts that will leave you on the edge of your seat. The visual effects seamlessly blend with the live-action, creating a truly immersive experience .Prabhas delivers a captivating performance as Lord Rama, capturing the essence of the revered deity with his commanding presence and emotional depth. Saif Ali Khan, in the role of Ravana, brings a mesmerizing intensity and complexity to the screen, making him a compelling antagonist.Adipurush" is a spectacular cinematic masterpiece that seamlessly blends myth and modern filmmaking. With its breathtaking visuals, stellar performances, and compelling storytelling, it captivates from start to finish.

review_title: A parody of the epic Ramayan, a cheap attempt to vulgarise the sacred story and mint quick bucks
review_text: There is always some creative liberty that should be allowed to an artist. It allows space for growth and quality to nurture. However, in this case, con artists Muntashir and Raut have taken incredible liberty to attend to only one fundamental cause, i.e. To make easy buck by exploiting the public image and sentiment woven over the sacred figure of Lord Ram, using the ready made story of Epic Ramayan and corrupting it with uncouth language and gestures, unnecessary and poorly done graphics, abysmally poor direction, poor choice of actors, extremely blend acting and screenplay. The only thing acceptable is the music. But that can be accessed through other means, no need to waste money on a shoddy film. The team is likely to face legal action soon for making a uncouth parody out of a sacred story and deluding public by advertising on the story of Ramayan in the pre release publicity, while taking a complete U-turn later and claiming that the movie is not ramayan but an adaptation of its story. This is a scam of hundreds of crores and must be punished both by legal means as well as by not contributing to footfall in theatres. Overall, a horrible movie and a short sighted attempt to make an easy business by abusing the popularity and sanctity of a religious story and then going overboard with poor direction, script and screenplay to bring total disgrace to it! The duo may have thought they will get away with it easily, but such heinous attempts to fool the public and make money off their sentiments will soon be taken up in the court! This movie has also shown how good actors like Prabhas can be turned into cartoons by immature cartoon directors like Om Raut.. to put it in a single phrase, this movie has proven to be a historic disappointment!

Pro: Brought the entire nation together. Together, to express disappointment.Con: The whole product.It takes a special kind of talent to misinterpret, no let me correct myself, disregard entire texts that have been part of the culture for many, many centuries. Makers say this was made for the youth, and by marketing the product like this, the makers continue to belittle the youth of the nation. The youth of this nation knows better, and deserves better still. Makers must be held accountable for this blunder and must publicly apologize for hurting national sentiment. The writer needs to stop trying to defend his role in this blunder, and the director (the real perpetrator behind the final product) must grow a spine and step out in the public view and apologize.1. Minimal or zero attention to details.2. Minimal or zero effort to give justice to character development.3. Minimal or zero research of the texts.4. Minimal or zero intellectual value in interpreting what creative liberty is and how much it should be exploited when making a film on such a crucial story.5. Minimal or zero effort in adapting the screenplay, from an already well established story.6. Minimal or zero respect for the art.7. Minimal or zero spiritual investment in the project.Overall, I might just lean more towards saying "zero", over saying "minimal".Every single person that has been involved in this project is at fault. The final product is abysmal, right from the casting to the designs to the makers to the execution. This "piece of art" makes you realise how long a minute actually is, because every second of it is a torture, like a needle being bore into your being extremely slowly and meticulously.Extremely poor characterization of every character in the film. Pathetic attempt at writing dialogues. Disgusting execution in terms of set designs, VFX, costumes. Not one element of the film can be appreciated, and yes, I do mean it. Adipurush, the highly anticipated mythological extravaganza, promises an epic retelling of a classic tale. However, this film falls miserably short of expectations, delivering a convoluted narrative with a collection of painfully bad dialogues and a misguided story that leave the audience scratching their heads in disbelief.The screenplay, or rather, the lack thereof, fails to establish a coherent plotline. Adipurush jumps haphazardly from one scene to another, leaving no room for character development or emotional investment. The pacing is erratic, veering between slow-motion sequences that feel like they're stuck in molasses and hyperactive action scenes that lack any sense of purpose or direction. It's a baffling mess that feels like it was edited together by a toddler with a pair of blunt scissors.But the real downfall of Adipurush lies in its dialogue. The lines uttered by the characters are so cringe-worthy and devoid of depth that it's hard not to burst into laughter during serious moments. The attempts at grandeur and profundity fall flat, as the characters spew out lines that sound like they were lifted from a cheap fantasy novel written by an angsty teenager. The dialogue is peppered with clichés and nonsensical metaphors that make you question the sanity of the screenwriters.The performances in Adipurush do little to salvage the train wreck of a script. The actors seem lost and confused, delivering their lines with an awkwardness that borders on painful to watch. Even the usually reliable and charismatic lead actor fails to bring any semblance of life to his character. It's as if the entire cast was given a sedative before filming, resulting in lackluster performances that add to the overall disappointment of the movie.Furthermore, the visual effects, which were touted as one of the film's strengths, are underwhelming and often distractingly artificial. The CGI feels unfinished and poorly integrated into the scenes, making it difficult to suspend disbelief and immerse oneself in the story. What should have been awe-inspiring battles between gods and demons end up looking like a subpar video game cutscene.In the end, Adipurush is a misguided attempt at creating an epic mythological film that falls flat on its face. The bad dialogue, muddled story, and uninspired performances make for a painful viewing experience. It's a shame that such a promising concept was wasted on this mess of a movie. Save your time and money, and look elsewhere for a worthwhile cinematic experience.Adipurush fails to capture the essence of the mythological tale it aims to depict. Instead, it offers a disjointed narrative that lacks depth and fails to engage the audience. The screenplay lacks coherence and jumps between scenes without providing any meaningful connection. It feels like a random assortment of events rather than a well-crafted story.One of the most glaring issues with Adipurush is its dialogue. The lines are cringe-inducing and lack any semblance of artistry. The characters' exchanges are filled with clichés and forced metaphors, making them sound shallow and unconvincing. It's as if the writers tried to create grandiose moments but ended up with a series of awkward and laughable exchanges instead.The performances in Adipurush do little to elevate the weak script. The actors appear lost and disconnected from their characters, delivering their lines with a lack of conviction. Even the talented lead actor fails to inject life into his role, leaving the audience disinterested and disconnected from the story. It's disheartening to see such a talented cast underutilized and wasted in a film that does not allow them to shine.Visually, Adipurush falls short of its promised spectacle. The CGI effects, which were expected to be a highlight, are unimpressive and poorly executed. The visual elements feel artificial and detached from the world of the film, making it difficult to suspend disbelief and immerse oneself in the story. The battles between gods and demons lack the grandeur and awe-inspiring quality they should have possessed, leaving the audience underwhelmed.In conclusion, Adipurush is a disappointing film that fails to deliver on its promises. The misguided story, filled with bad dialogue and weak performances, leaves the audience disconnected and disinterested. The lackluster visual effects further contribute to the overall disappointment. It's a missed opportunity to bring a beloved mythological tale to life in a captivating and engaging manner. Save your time and seek out a better cinematic experience elsewhere.

No mention of astr use by Shri Ram......no mention of Angad's story......No mention of the pushpak viman.....and many more such things.Please don't let your kids watch this movie.Cultural Sensitivity: One of the main concerns about "Adipurush" is how it handles the cultural and religious sensitivities associated with the source material, the Ramayana. Some critics argue that adapting such a revered epic into a commercial film risks diluting its spiritual and moral teachings for the sake of entertainment.Historical Accuracy: The movie, like many adaptations of mythological stories, may take artistic liberties with the source material for dramatic effect. This can lead to inaccuracies in portraying the characters, events, and themes of the original epic. Critics might argue that altering the story could potentially misrepresent the core messages of the Ramayana.Commercialization of Religion: Some critics view "Adipurush" as an example of the commercialization of religious narratives. By turning a sacred story into a big-budget film, there's a concern that the primary focus could shift from the spiritual and ethical aspects of the epic to profit-making.Casting Choices: The casting decisions for the film have also come under scrutiny. The choice of actors for iconic characters can significantly impact the perception of the adaptation. Critics might question whether the chosen actors can authentically capture the essence of characters like Lord Rama, Sita, and Ravana.

Firstly, I am not a Ram worshipper or Hindu. However, I still like the Ramayana story a lot. Therefore this review will be a little less emotionally charged than the others. I believe in accepting all and varied perspectives on a topic."Adipurush" is a modern retelling of the ancient Sanskrit ballad Ramayana, which is an important text of Hindu scripture. The story of the Ramayana is essentially a love story- between Prince Ram, an incarnation of the god Vishnu, and his wife Princess Sita, herself an incarnation of Vishnu's consort Lakshmi. The ballad contains various discussions on moral and philosophical themes, interwoven throughout the narrative."Adipurush" makes some decent attempts at adapting the story for a modern audience, but fails miserably in several aspects. For one, the CGI and visual effects are terrible. There are multiple sequences where the computer graphics are painfully obvious. Some of the shot compositions and cinematography was pretty great though. The fruit of those 600 crores are barely visible.I like the stylised and simple designs of all the costumes, weapons and characters. Unfortunately, keeping a few key details accurate (such as giving Ram and Lakshman yellow trousers instead of white) would have been good. Additionally, it is ideal for fantasy and mythological characters to have long hair rather than shorter hairstyles that resemble modern looks, which takes you really far away from the world of the film. The "Rakshasas" or demons are given fades and Mohawks which do not suit the world of "Adipurush" at all.Similar issues such as featuring gorillas in the monkey tribe and depicting Lanka (Ravana's kingdom) as sooty black (as opposed to the beautiful city of gold as described in the original story) are present as well. The ballad describes Sita as giving her head brooch (which Ram placed on her on their wedding night) to Hanuman as a token to take back to him, but she gives one of her bracelets to the mighty monkey god instead.The screenplay is written not for a general audience, but for people who know the story of the Ramayana really well. As a result, several of the character motivations are unclear (or even missing) and characters lack development or depth. The film should have, in my opinion, been a two-parter like Mani Ratnam's "Ponniyin Selvan", with the first half describing the birth of Ram and Sita, followed by their love story, Kaikeyi's (Ram's stepmother) machinations against Ram and his exile to the forest. The second half should have focused on Sita's kidnapping by Ravana and her subsequent rescue by Ram, Lakshman and the monkeys and bears.One does not get a real sense of Ram's character or Ravana's corruption. Hanuman, Ravana and Meghnad (Ravana's son) seem to have been done dirty the most in the screenplay. Sita is done some justice though. Poor Lakshman is tremendously under-utilised.For some reason, the characters of Ram, Sita, Lakshman and Hanuman are never called by those names, but Ravana and everyone else is called by their own names. The songs feature the names "Ram" and "Siya (another form of the name "Sita")", but the characters are called "Raghav" and "Janaki" instead. The depictions of other divine beings in the Hindu pantheon is pretty disrespectful (the most prominent example being Brahma, who has to literally refer to himself as such in the movie- there is otherwise no way you can tell that it's Brahma).The epic describes the monkey physician Sushena as the one who heals Lakshman from a deadly wound inflicted on him by Meghnad. However, a seemingly new character created for the film- Vibhishan's (Ravana's younger brother who takes Ram's side during the war) wife is the one who heals Lakshman. There was a brief shot of her cleavage during an expository scene, which seems to have been removed for the OTT release. Some controversial bits of dialogue have also been dubbed over in the latest cut of the film. Odd additions to the story include a massive dragon that Ravana uses to fly around in and Meghnad having what seems to be super speed.I found myself appreciating the film more on my second watch. Even though Prabhas was miscast as Ram, I think he did a decent job in the role. Unfortunately, it felt a bit too much like Amarendra Baahubali. Kriti Sanon gave a beautiful performance as Sita and played the character with great conviction and grace. Devdutta Nage and Sunny Singh need to take some acting classes. Saif Ali Khan is a beast of an actor, but the script did him no justice. Not to mention the terrible design for the character's looks.A few sequences look pretty great- most notably the romantic scenes with Ram and Sita, as well as the scene where the monkeys construct the floating bridge (Ram Setu). I felt those scenes were done pretty well. Everything else looked amateur, sometimes even trash.The final battle felt incredibly lacklustre. A lot of the shots seems to have been lifted straight from other movies, including Prabhas' "Baahubali", the first "Avengers" film and "Lord of The Rings". This is disheartening to see as someone who has seen older adaptations of the Ramayana legend that had some amazing original sequences and shots that still induce chills today.Perhaps the only saving grace of the film is the music. The songs by Ajay-Atul are great to listen to, but seem detached from the visuals when they appear during the movie. The background score does most of the heavy lifting for selling the epic nature of the story.All in all, I felt that the film had great potential, but it was extremely disappointing. The movie fails to appeal to the modern audience it desperately craves for and does not respect the source material to even a serviceable degree. I do not recommend this film if you want to learn about Indian history or religion, or even if you want to watch a non-Hollywood fantasy film. You could watch this just to kill some time though.I would recommend the following series and films to get a better idea of the Ramayana story:1. Ramanand Sagar's "Ramayan" (1987 Hindi TV series)
2. NDTV's "Ramayan" (2008 Hindi TV series)
3. Bapu's "Sampoorna Ramayanam" (1972 Telugu film)
4. Bapu's "Seetha Rama Kalyanam" (1976 Telugu film)
5. Yugo Sako and Ram Mohan's "Ramayana: The Legend of Prince Ram" (1992 English/Hindi animated film)

review_title: Adipurush: The Ultimate Lesson in Massacring a Film With Immense Potential
review_text:
Adipurush is an extremely tame adaptation of the Ramayana, one of the greatest ancient Indian epics. It is a film that does not seem to take itself too seriously and sacrifices logic at the altar of excesses. It is excruciatingly long and painfully slow in the way it pans out. While the length of the film is not necessarily a bad thing, the bemusing storyline and the extremely bland characters ensure that the film is an unintentionally hilarious snooze-fest. It is a comedy of errors which only goes from bad to worse. The film operates in extremes, with characters such as Ravana being the epitome of murderous evil without any redeeming quality whatsoever. The other characters too are, unfortunately, devoid of any impact, with multiple key characters being entirely left out of the film.The film, whether advertently or inadvertently, comes across as a bad copy of Western popular culture content such as Ghost Rider, Game of Thrones, Harry Potter, Planet of the Apes and Marvel films. At places, the film comes across as a frustrating hodge-podge comprising a standard Bollywood action-thriller, a classic Bollywood romantic film and a substandard Bollywood horror flick. What could have been a breakthrough film for the Bollywood film industry to prove the calibre of Indian filmmakers at the global stage turns out to be yet another run-of-the-mill film that proves to be a nightmare for it's makers. The film's dialogues are quite pallid, predictable and laughable, with the 'simple language' used by the makers including unnecessary slangs such as 'fisaddi', 'dho dunga', 'jalegi' and 'phoonk' in a bid to 'make the film relatable to younger audiences'.What ensues is absolute chaos. The dialogues only go to show the lack of creativity and lazy writing that eclipses even the largely simplistic dialogue writing evident in Brahmastra, which is still miles ahead of this film in terms of being a decent watch that one can return to multiple times. The divine characters in the film do not exude any divinity whatsoever. The film is replete with comical instances of contemporary ideals of fashion being shoved into an ancient era, as is evident from the hairstyles, sarees and tatoo designs present in the film. The chimpanzees in the Vanar sena and the hideous monsters in Ravana's demon army make no sense either. The film had multiple possibilities and could have gone any way. Alas, the makers seemed too intent on self-destructing.While creative liberties are acceptable and previous adaptations of a certain text need not necessarily be adhered to, the film makes a mess of even the basic essence of the Ramayana and the events present in it. Add to it a substandard VFX that couldn't even match that of Brahmastra, a dark, gloomy and depressing colour scheme and cringeworthy action sequences, and the film is the perfect recipie for disaster. It doesn't help either that the character based on Lord Ram comes across as a typical Bollywood romantic hero and angry young man, and the women in the film barely have any say in the goings on, serving merely as embellishments to adorn a male-dominated world. All in all, Adipurush is a massive disappointment.While it does have it's moments and does have certain positives such as the soothing songs, the fantastic background score, the commendable acting of the entire cast as per the script, the opening montage, the closing montage, the battle between Ravana and Raghav and a scene in which the main characters appear together, these are not enough to salvage what turns out be a comedy session on the whole. The supposedly 'encouraging' monologues delivered by Raghav to his army prior to the battle are not motivational from any stretch of the imagination and turn out to be yawn-inducing. The film has very poor production values and third-grade sets that can put Chhota Bheem to shame. By the time the credits roll out, you are bound to feel miserable for those who worked on this film.On the whole, Adipurush is a catastrophe that rightly tanked at the box office. It's hard to belive that this film has been directed by the director of Tanhaji. Neither Om Raut nor Manoj Muntashir can justify this atrocious film. While the film is decent to watch once if you have nothing better to do, it is not advisable to watch this film if you value your life and time. Save your brain cells and find something better to watch.Adipurush- What could have been better:1. The length of the film could have been revised.2. The battle scenes could have been compressed and the time remaining could have been used to focus on the characters who received absolutely no screen time in the film. The battle scenes could also have been more well thought out rather than being made to look like mindless fighting.3. The language could have been a bit more representative of that used in ancient India and by divinity while still being simple. Slangs such as 'jalegi', 'fisaddi', 'dho dunga' and 'phoonk' could have been avoided.4. The VFX team could have taken assistance from trained overseas professionals who have
experiences of working with films with high quality VFX. The colour scheme could have been more varied.5. The costumes, set designs and hairstyles could have been better researched and made more appropriate to ancient India. The tattoos were absolutely unnecessary and could have been avoided.6. The makers could have avoided copying the West. They could also have avoided making the film a confusing Bollywood masala film of sorts. More original ideas could have been sought by the makers with regard to adapting the Ramayana into a film and they could have come up with something unique.7. The women could have been given far more agency in the film. The characters in general could have been more nuanced and complex rather than embodying extreme personalities. The divine characters could have been worked on with greater care.8. Attempts could have been made to maintain the basic essence of the Ramayana and to at least present basic events in a more captivating manner.

review_title: Great Movie. Must Watch. Don't believe reviews watch it to live it.
review_text: Movie Review: "Adipurush"Rating: 10/10"Adipurush" is a magnum opus that captures the essence of epic storytelling and delivers a cinematic experience of epic proportions. Directed by visionary filmmaker, this monumental retelling of an age-old mythological tale is a testament to the prowess of Indian cinema and its ability to transport audiences into a mythical world filled with grandeur, emotion, and larger-than-life characters.One of the most remarkable aspects of "Adipurush" is its impeccable production design and awe-inspiring visuals. The attention to detail in recreating ancient kingdoms, elaborate costumes, and intricate sets is truly commendable. Each frame is a visual spectacle, immersing the audience in a world that feels both authentic and fantastical. The stunning cinematography beautifully captures the scale and grandeur of the story, making it a feast for the eyes.The performances in "Adipurush" are nothing short of outstanding. The lead actors breathe life into their characters, portraying their depth and complexities with remarkable skill. Their chemistry on screen is palpable, making the emotional moments all the more impactful. The supporting cast also shines, adding layers of richness to the narrative.The film's screenplay strikes a perfect balance between staying true to the mythological source material and infusing it with a fresh perspective. It skillfully weaves together themes of love, sacrifice, and the eternal battle between good and evil. The dialogues are powerful and resonant, delivering memorable lines that will linger in the minds of the audience long after the movie ends.Another highlight of "Adipurush" is its breathtaking action sequences. The meticulously choreographed battles are a visual treat, showcasing the prowess and strength of the lead characters. The combination of practical stunts and cutting-edge visual effects creates moments of awe and excitement that leave the audience on the edge of their seats.The film's soundtrack deserves special mention for its ability to heighten the emotional impact of each scene. The haunting melodies and powerful background score perfectly complement the visuals, adding depth and intensity to the storytelling."Adipurush" is not just a cinematic experience; it is a celebration of our rich mythological heritage. It reminds us of the timeless themes and lessons that have shaped our culture for centuries. It is a film that evokes a sense of pride and admiration, leaving the audience with a renewed appreciation for our traditions and storytelling.In conclusion, "Adipurush" is an absolute triumph on every level. It combines breathtaking visuals, outstanding performances, a gripping storyline, and a powerful emotional core to create a cinematic experience that is truly unforgettable. This epic tale will resonate with audiences of all ages and stand as a testament to the artistic brilliance of Indian cinema.
